The balance of the land not handed over to the community will remain in the ownership of the Department of Defence.

Townsville is set to get a magnificent extension to our famous Strand following hard work to get Defence to agree to give most of the historic and prime land at Jezzine Barracks to the community. The community has been listened to and more than half of the land will go for community purposes. Both the North Queensland Military Heritage Association and the RSL have achieved what they wanted. However, Defence is also a key stakeholder and it will continue to own the balance of the land, to be used for Defence purposes. No land will be sold to developers and there will be no high-rises. This is a good outcome for all key stakeholders. The Defence precinct will only house ADF personnel.

For my part, I have been working on some very innovative ways to enhance the historic areas and to provide the connection from the Strand to Rowes Bay. I have been particularly impressed with the fully integrated peace park concept I saw on Saipan Island. With the RSL and the new North Queensland Military Museum and the mayor, I reckon we can do the same, if not better. Some great Indigenous ideas have also come forward. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to extend our magnificent Strand and to preserve our military heritage for future generations.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on behalf of my constituent Mr Rocco Nuzzo of Oatley. Mr Nuzzo is the victim of what appears to be an inconsistency in the application of the Social Security Act to his personal circumstances. Mr Nuzzo receives a gross fortnightly benefit of $443.50 from the New South Wales Dust Diseases Board. My office has been advised by the Minister for Family and Community Services that this payment is treated as a compensation payment; therefore, he is not entitled to receive a pension, with its corresponding concession card. Mr Nuzzo is diagnosed as 40 per cent impaired by the Dust Diseases Board, so he is unable to work. He has no investments, so has not been able to accumulate funds. The great irony in this is that, if Mr Nuzzo had investments or if he were able to work, he would only be assessed at 40c in the dollar instead of dollar for dollar.

speech.para: What type of social security net is this government providing? Here we have a man diagnosed with a 40 per cent disability by the Dust Diseases Board yet, because he is not rich enough to accumulate investments and he is too ill to work, he is seriously disadvantaged. He is unable to access the concession card, which would provide him with discounts on council rates, car registration and so on. Yet he is able to access some PBS prescription items and specified Medicare services at a cheaper rate. He is able to access ancillary benefits to assist with his condition.

What of the inconsistency in this policy? Why should Mr Nuzzo be so disadvantaged? If he were able to work, he would be assessed at 40c in the dollar, not dollar for dollar. If he had financial investments, he would be assessed at 40c in the dollar, not dollar for dollar. Yet, because he is dependent on benefits, he is assessed at a different rate. Where is the equity in this situation? Mr Nuzzo could access benefits through his wifeâs pension card. However, he is a proud man who would prefer not to do so. That aside, though, how would he manage if his wife did not have a pension card? It does beg the question: what of single people in this equation? Time after time, my office receives calls from people facing such policy inconsistencies. Such people have to deal with the mean spirit of this government.

I asked earlier: where is the fairness and equity in this situation? Obviously this is a rhetorical question. There is no fairness and equity in a system provided by a government which is ideologically driven. People like Mr Nuzzo are the proverbial meat in the sandwich between the federal government and the insurance companies: the government insists that the insurance companies should pay more compensation; the insurance companies insist that they want to keep premiums low. Inevitably it is the individuals who suffer.

Mr Nuzzo believes the government accepts that people cannot live on the pension. Hence, they are allowed to earn up to $220 per fortnight before losing 40c in the dollar for income earned over that amount. Mr Nuzzo, on the other hand, earns an income from his dust diseases payment yet he is unable to claim a pension, which is calculated, because of the type of income, as dollar for dollar. Categorically, this is one further example of an uncaring, inconsistent and unsympathetic government.

talk.start.para: âLike other honourable members, I have had the opportunity in recent weeks to attend a number of senior award presentation nights at schools in my electorate situated on Queenslandâs Sunshine Coast. These nights involve the entire school communityâparents, bothers, sisters, grandparents, high school executives and board members, local dignitaries and teachers, of courseâall coming together to celebrate the achievements of the senior students as well as to wish them well as they make the transition into the next stage of their lives.

speech.para: I have been particularly impressed with the standard of these students, and the award ceremonies have highlighted the dedication and drive that so many young people have in our society today. I am impressed at the way in which, during their period at secondary school, they have been involved in school and community activities and at the way in which they have been determined to be positive role models not only for their schools but also for younger students. I am also impressed by their enthusiasm on the sporting fields and their positive attitudes towards their school work. In Australia we are so quick to criticise, but these young people must be congratulated on being so positive. They are a valued and valuable part of my community in the electorate Fisher on the Sunshine Coast.

These award ceremonies take place at numbers of schools. In fact, I attended three award ceremonies on one evening, and, with my parliamentary responsibilities here in Canberra, I have also had staff represent me at several school events. It is important to recognise that school students are the potential of this country, and we really ought to do all that we can to support them. Unfortunately, I think in Australia we so often tend to criticise young people and we do not look at the fact that they are offering so much hope and so much opportunity for our nationâs future.

I would like to take this opportunity in the Main Committee to encourage Australiaâs youth to believe in themselves, to be dedicated and hardworking, and to understand that they are playing a very important role in our national life. I make these comments somewhat as a rebuttal to some of the negative media coverage we see from time to time about young people.

talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

âYoung people are often easy scapegoats when one is looking for someone to blame when graffiti appears or some other nuisance crime such as vandalism happens to occur. Our youth must be praised for their positive qualities and their enthusiasm and be reminded of their potential, and I thank the member for Bowman for his vocal support. Youth are a demographic that has been affected by increased levels of depression and suicide, and I personally find this is one the greatest worries and one of the greatest challenges that we have as a nation. Michelle Ellis, one of my staff, has read negative reports about our youth, but she thinks it is high time that the positive achievements and potential of young people are given a hearing and that they deserve ongoing encouragement and support. I support Michelleâs view. I think these young people are Australiaâs future. (Time expired)

âI rise to speak on an issue that I, like many Australians, feel passionately about: Australian rules football. My office has received an increasing number of calls concerning AFL plans to grant exclusive broadcasting rights to pay TV for home-game AFL football matches played outside Melbourne. Not surprisingly, people are upset and angry at reports that they may be unable to access Adelaide Crows and Port Power home game football matches on free-to-air TV. Today I would like to take this opportunity to voice my constituentsâ opposition to this matter, to remind the government of the antisiphoning laws currently in place and to insist that the government ensure that the AFL stays within those laws.

speech.para: Sport is part of Australian culture and, frankly, having to pay $50 each month to be able to watch the mighty Adelaide Crows or, if people so choose, Port Power play on TV is unacceptable. More than a decade ago the previous Labor government established an antisiphoning regime aimed at ensuring that rights to certain events were not sold to pay TV until free-to-air networks were given reasonable opportunity to purchase those rights. This regime has never prevented events being shown on pay TV and does not guarantee free-to-air broadcasters exclusive rights. Rather, the antisiphoning regime is about ensuring that major sporting events are available to all Australians on free-to-air television.

Last football season three AFL matches per round were shown by Foxtel, while the rest were aired on free-to-air TV. Yet the AFL seems intent on turning its back on football fans, instead wanting to negotiate an agreement that grants pay TV exclusive broadcasting rights to the home games of the Sydney Swans, the Brisbane Lions, the West Coast Eagles, the Fremantle Dockers and, most importantly, the Adelaide Crows and Port Power.

South Australian football fans have had it far too hard for too long. Our clubs travelâthey have more away gamesâand, unlike many of those Victorian clubs, do not get the easy run that they are granted. As a Crows supporter, I know that our club is so popular that fans have to go on a waiting list to get membership to the club. Home games are regularly sold out, giving many fans no choice but to watch it on television. I would also not want to forget our country fans, who rely on free-to-air television rights in order to tune into their favourite game.

There has been a lot of talk about the rise of soccer in our communities. I would like to say to the AFL that it is hardly the time for them to be taking footy fans for granted. If the AFL gets its way, football fans will have to pay up to $600 a year to watch their teamâs home game matches. As one of my constituents so rightly pointed out, forcing people to pay any sum to watch their favourite team play at home is unfair, and it is particularly unfair to people who cannot afford to purchase pay TV. Sport should remain accessible to all Australians on free-to-air television. I call on Andrew Demetriou and the AFL commission to value footy supporters, including Adelaide Crows and Port Power supporters, who want nothing more than to be able to watch their teams. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to praise the wonderful efforts of Australian volunteers, although more particularly those volunteers in my electorate of Stirling. During the course of my duties, I meet with a large number of organisations who have volunteers who, with no expectation of remuneration, give up their time and often raise money to assist a cause that is important to them.

speech.para: On 5 December this year organisations such as Volunteering WA will celebrate International Volunteer Day. There are a large number of organisations with whom I have regular contactâthe Balga and the Nollamara-Westminster action groups are examples of groups who contribute to both the social and cultural atmosphere in their areas. Their activities are of great benefit to the community, and I thank all involved for their dedication and constructive activism.

I would like to congratulate the city of Stirlingâs Stirling Volunteer Transport, who recently celebrated 25 years of operation. Stirling Volunteer Transport is an important link that provides aged and disabled members of the community with access to services and facilities that they would otherwise be unable to utilise. In numerical terms, this equates to approximately 2,000 trips for 350 people each month within Stirling. Without this valuable service, many aged and infirm people would lose their link to the outside world. I commend all involved for their compassion and contribution to those in the community who require outside assistance.

Stirling Coastcare is also an important volunteer community organisation within my electorate. The beautiful coastline that borders the electorate of Stirling is maintained and rehabilitated by Stirling Coastcare, and many members of my community actively participate in this organisation. Stirling Coastcare is responsible for the wonderful work along the coastline, and I am always grateful for the enthusiasm and strong sense of community of its members. Volunteers are invaluable to our community, yet often they are overlooked.

I am lucky enough to have the opportunity to be regularly assisted in my electorate office by volunteers. The volunteers who assist in my office generally have very inauspicious jobs such as stuffing envelopes, but they enable me to communicate with my electorate about what the Howard government is doing for the people of Australia. More importantly, with volunteers assisting my staff in the collation of surveys and information, I am able to address the issues of real concern to my electors and to work on what the government can do to improve these services. I would like to thank the always dependable Nick and Mona Katavatis, Ian and Val MacLean, Margie Gray, Sally Suba and the always present Liz Needer, who gives so much of her time to assist the people of Stirling. There are many others who have assisted me but time, unfortunately, limits me from listing them today. I commend the activities of volunteers to the House, and I encourage all Australians to reflect on the role of the volunteer. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! In accordance with standing order 193, the time for membersâ statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: MIGRATION AND OMBUDSMAN LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr McGauran:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Burke moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

item.para: notes that, for the bill to be effective in delivering more humane treatment of detainees, it is essential that the culture within the Department of Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs needs to change;

recognises that the independent reports produced by Mr Mick Palmer AO APM and by the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Prof. John McMillan, of an inquiry undertaken by Mr Neil Comrie AO APM, each conclude that the cultural problems became entrenched in the years leading up to 2001;
condemns the refusal by the then Minister for Immigration and current Attorney-General to take responsibility for that culture;
condemns the refusal by the current Minister for Immigration to take responsibility for the continuation of that culture;
agrees with the finding of Mr Palmerâs report that âReform must come from the topâ and therefore calls on the Prime Minister to dismiss the Attorney-General and the Minister for Immigration;
calls on the Government to take action to terminate the contracts which outsource the management of detention centres to Global Solutions Ltd; and
calls on the Government to return the management of detention centres to the Commonwealth and locate all detention centres on Commonwealth Territoryâ.

talk.start.para: âIf we reflect on the events of a number of years past up to this present point in time in relation to immigration issues in this country, and if we consider the plethora of inquiriesâand there are two important ones that I will refer to a little later in my speechâmedia coverage of what has happened in relation to the immigration department and a headline such as âSomething rotten in Immigrationâ, which I have in front of me at the moment, picked at random, as it wereâa report by Mike Steketee, the national affairs editor of the Australian, on the Palmer reportâI think it is fair to say that we have witnessed a particularly difficult and at times disturbing era in the administration of a federal bureaucracy and the appropriate policy settings, governance and leadership that have been put in place by successive ministers of the Howard government.

speech.para: There is no doubt that immigration, really, has been the leitmotiv of the Howard era. When the history is written in a detached sense in some years to come, I do not thinkâand I say this with some regretâthat there is any doubt whatsoever that historians will judge the era very harshly. They will judge the department harshly and they will reflect on the leadership of the department. But, most importantlyâand I do not seek to reflect on the current leadership of the department todayâthey will reflect on the leadership that was offered by the government on this issue, particularly by the Prime Minister; the former Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, the now Attorney-General, Mr Ruddock; and the existing minister, Senator Vanstone.

It is fair to say that the public has an expectation that government departments would not only observe all the appropriate bureaucratic policy and legislative and other protocols that are within their remit but, at the same time, ensure that the duty of care they owe, particularly in departments like Immigration, to the people over whom they ultimately have some responsibility is exercised prudently and compassionately. In the cases that I will refer to today, it is very clear that that has not happened.

What is most disturbing about the saga of events that has transpired over the past several years is not that the department has not come to an understanding and an admission that it could do things better. It has, and that is acknowledged by members on this side of the House and by others. It is that the departmentâs political masters, the Prime Minister and now Senator Vanstone, have refused in any way whatsoever to take accountability for what has happened. It is fair to say, particularly in relation to the Palmer report, the Comrie report and the series of events that surrounded both Ms Rau and Ms Solon Alvarez, that the idea of ministerial responsibility literally went out the window altogether.

I do note that the member for Kooyong will speak following me. I want to put on the record my appreciation of the efforts of the member for Kooyong, the member for Pearce and others in the government who have worked assiduously to ensure that the duty of care that I have just referred to, which ought to be exercised as a matter of course by a government department with these responsibilities, has in some ways been enhanced and improved. But, from the record of what the Prime Minister and Minister Vanstone have said, it is very clear that the whole-of-government position has simply been to carry on as though very little has happenedâand no-one, still, has been judged responsible. There will be many speeches, and there probably have been many made that I am not aware of, that go to the heart of this issue. I suspect that there will be many more made, both in this parliament and in the community, until responsibility is acknowledged by those who truly are responsibleâthe ministers in question.

Minister Ruddock made an art form of encouraging people to think poorly either of those who sought to come here as refugees or of those who were in the immigration system. He turned it into an art form, which I think reflects politics at its worst. The legion of claims that he has made, as both minister for immigration and Attorney-General, that are either false, misleading or incorrect, are many. As immigration minister it was not above the ministerâ

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! The member for Kingsford Smith should withdraw the word âfalseâ. I do not think that can be accepted.

âI withdraw that expression, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you suggest. I certainly will retain the expression âmisleadingâ for the moment. I refer to the claim that the minister made when he was the minister for immigration that Australia took its fair share of refugees into the country and compared us to equivalent Western countries where the rate, as memory serves me, was about 26 per cent and Australiaâs rate was about 13 per cent. That claim was actually wrong.

speech.para: Politicians and political leaders may have remained indifferent to the levels of concern about the integrity of the processes that were under way, both in respect of immigration and also in its oversight. But the public were not indifferent. One of the things that has been most noticeable to me has been the increasing number of ordinary Australiansâand I think of Rural Australians for Refugeesâwho decided that they had to speak up on this issue, that they had to work with politicians on both sides of the House who had some concerns about this issue and additionally that they would work in the community to ensure that some representation of a public kind in respect of what was going on could take place. I endorse the member for Watsonâs remarks in the debate on the second reading amendment. There is no doubt that both the Palmer report recommendations and the Comrie inquiryâs report showed very clearly that the state of the department was catastrophicâthose were words that were used.
I refer to the Palmer reportâs main findings in respect of Ms Rau, and I will identify a couple of these main findings in my remarks. Main finding No. 4 says:

quote.para: There is no automatic process of review sufficient to provide confidence to the Government, to the Secretary of DIMIA or to the public that the power to detain a person on reasonable suspicion of being an unlawful non-citizen under s. 189(1) of the Commonwealthâs Migration Act 1958 is being exercised lawfully, justifiably and with integrity.

speech.para: That is an astonishing finding by Mr Palmer. Finding No. 5 says:

quote.para: The case complexity and workload associated with enforcing and managing immigration detention policy have placed much pressure on DIMIA staff.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
The speed of change to the immigration detention environment since 2000 has led to policy, procedures and enabling structures being developed on the run.

speech.para: One has to ask the question: what was the minister doing at this point in time when policy changes were putting such pressure and stress on officers within the department? Finding No. 8, which has been extensively remarked on in the press, says:

quote.para: There is a serious cultural problem within DIMIAâs immigration compliance and detention areas: urgent reform is necessary.

speech.para: Finding No. 9 says:

quote.para: DIMIA officers are authorised to exercise exceptional, even extraordinary, powers. That they should be permitted and expected to do so without adequate training, without proper management and oversight, with poor information systems, and with no genuine quality assurance and constraints on the exercise of these powers is of concern. The fact that this situation has been allowed to continue unchecked and unreviewed for several years is difficult to understand.

speech.para: And so it goes on; the story is well understood. The department and the ministers in question have made their responses. I do not doubt that there is a genuine desire within the department, and from officers within the department, to heed this report and subsequent reports, but when we look at the way in which the responses of ministers and other departments have played out in publicâand we are still left with a feeling of the publicâs expectation of genuine, bona fide sincerityâthere has certainly been no contrition. Genuine, bona fide sincerity in addressing these issues has not yet been made clear to the Australian public, and it certainly has not been felt on this side of the House.

Let me refer to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which I think has been particularly remiss in understanding the necessary cultural and process changes that ought to take place in relation to the Comrie report. As you will know, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, the Comrie reportâs findings about Vivian Alvarez Solon were also damning. The history is a tragic one, made more so by the fact it was clear that the omissions, failures and incapacities of the department increased the misery of this woman and in fact contributed to the situation that she found herself in. She was found injured in a park in Lismore on 30 March 2001. She was first interviewed by DIMIA officers on 3 May. The DIMIA officers did not seek access to hospital records that contained personal information that would have helped to have identified her, and they did not actively pursue a male friend of hers in Lismore who had information that would have helped to identify her. I am picking out some of the aspects of the reportâbecause I know they have been well reportedâbut it does paint the picture of what actually happened.

DIMIA officers conducted a formal interview with Ms Solon on 13 July. She said she was an Australian citizen at that time, that she wanted to remain in Australia and that she wanted to apply for a visa. Comrie remarks:

quote.para: Inadequate action was taken by DIMIA to pursue these crucial remarks.

speech.para: He points out:

quote.para: The inquiries made in an attempt to identify Vivian were ad hoc and symptomatic of a situation in which DIMIA officers had been inadequately trained for their role as compliance officers,Â particularly in relation to the interrogation of IT systems and databases.

speech.para: Certainly there was a great deal of reportage at the time and a subsequent response by the department about the necessity for the department to have far more rigorous, accountable and transparent processes but particularly to enhance the IT capacity within the department. The report goes on to say:

quote.para: The management of Vivianâs case was very poor, lacking rigour and accountability

speech.para: The reportâs main finding No. 10 states:

quote.para: The DIMIA officers involved in Vivianâs case had a flawed understanding of the application and implications of s. 189 of the Migration Act 1958.

speech.para: I think it is very fair to ask in the parliament how it is that immigration officers can have a flawed understanding of the application and implications of their governing act. How is it that officers who have this level of responsibility do not know what is in the law and that the life of this woman, in particular, was jeopardised as a consequence of their ignorance of that? A litany of mistakes, a history of errors goes on in her case. For example, finding No. 15 states:

quote.para: Although DIMIA officers were presented with a difficult decision about where to detain Vivian before removing herâ

speech.para: and, as we know, she ended up in the Philippinesâ

quote.para: her detention for one week in a single motel room was inappropriate. Her privacy, dignity and welfare were compromised by the fact that she was guarded in this room at all times by two contracted security guards and had no access to the medical facilities available to people held in immigration detention centres.

speech.para: What were people thinking? Did they believe that this woman was a risk to national security? What possible reason was there, I pose the question, as to why she should have been treated in this way?

Finally, once the Philippine embassy had expressed concerns about Vivianâs fitness to travelâand when I say âfinallyâ, there is a significant history there that I do not have the time to go through at this pointâand would not issue a travel document allowing for her removal to the Philippines, there was the use of a locum medical practitioner to certify Vivian as fit to travel, but Mr Comrie finds that this was inappropriate in the circumstances. So the findings go on and on. Frankly, if it were not for the efforts of Robert Young, Ms Solon Alvarezâs former husband, who knows what ultimately would have happened? Finding No. 34 states:

quote.para: DIMIAâs overall management of Vivianâs case can only be described as catastrophic.

speech.para: However, that finding goes on to say:

quote.para: ... it is important to record that some DIMIA officers performed their duties diligently and professionally ...

speech.para: And I do not doubt that at all. What I do doubt is that the message has got through to the government and, frankly, to some bureaucrats as well. I referred earlier to DFAT. In the Comrie report we read that, despite being aware on 9 September 2003 that Vivian had been wrongfully deported in 2001, theyâthat is, DFAT officersâtreated the matter as an inquiry for information about a third party and did not create a case file. It really beggars belief. They simply supplied the information to the Missing Persons Bureau and did nothing else. What reason was offered for that? The rules only require a follow-up and creation of a case file if a query comes from a family member. This speaks to me of bureaucracy going terribly wrong.

The communications on Ms Solon Alvarez were by email. The department then said that, if they had been by cable, they would have been noticed. If I did not notice my email communications because I preferred to receive letters and was instructed that I should read only communications that came to me by letter and ignore all the emails of the many millions that fly around the world every second of the dayâcommunications used by every person in this roomâI would be doing my job very poorly. They did their job very poorly. The DFAT line was the classic defence of âdoing it by the bookââthe consular handbook, in that case. No wonder Mr Comrie remarked:

quote.para: It might well be that bureaucratic requirements were met in this case, but the Inquiry is of the view that important obligations to an Australian citizen were not met.Â

speech.para: There were other examples. Despite department assurances that systems will be tightened in the future, you are left with the feeling that the neglect that goes to the heart of how this woman was treated is consistent with the governmentâs political posture and political policy as enunciated at the beginning of the election campaign, when the statement was made by the Prime Minister: âWe decide who comes into the country.â That is very clearly the impression that you get.

In my remarks, I want to say very clearly that we on this side acknowledge the good and hard work that is done by public servants within government departments of the Federation. I personally recognise that people give of themselves in public service. I know that many would be feeling a great sense of regret that the issues that I have travailed very lightly today have reflected so poorly on their department.

While the former head of the department, Mr Farmer, becoming the ambassador to Indonesia may or may not have been a choice that he made, it was certainly a decision that the Prime Minister made. It was a decision of great eloquence, because it spoke to the heart of how this government sees these particular issues and the way in which it is prepared to either reward or condemn on the basis of not what is happening in terms of substantive policy but what it thinks it can get away with politically.

There has been something rotten in Immigrationâof that there is no doubt. We do, though, support this bill, and we recognise that the government is implementing some measures which we think will improve the administration of immigration policy. The need for there to be more flexibility and fairness and for it to happen in a more timely manner is to be acknowledged. Labor has a more progressive policy, and it has been enumerated by a number of members here, and so I commend that policy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI wish to speak in support of the Migration and Ombudsman Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. I welcome the support of the Labor Party and the member for Kingsford-Smith for the bill as a whole. In June this year the government resolved to implement a package of reforms for the immigration detention system. These reforms sought to achieve a very substantial improvement to the fairness, transparency and compassion in our immigration detention policy. They also sought to expedite decisions on protection visa applications. This bill is the second legislative component of these reforms. The first component was the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Act, which was enacted in June.

speech.para: The policy of mandatory detention was introduced by the Labor government in 1992, fearing a flood of unauthorised refugees. Further stringent measures were subsequently adopted by the Howard government to deter people from entering Australia and from seeking asylum here. Thankfully, the atmosphere of crisis surrounding these measures has passed. A combination of factors has seen a sharp fall in the number of asylum seekers and refugees globally, and unauthorised boat arrivals have largely ceasedâthat is, until the start of this month no asylum seekers had been apprehended in Australian waters for over two years. I will say more about these most recent arrivals in a moment, but first I want to return to the impetus for the recent reforms.

There was compelling evidence of the pressing need for reform of the mandatory detention policy. Across the Australian community there were deep concerns that the system had become excessively rigid and harsh and had harmed vulnerable children, women and men. Reforms needed to ensure that, while we effectively protected our borders, we were humane and just to those affected by our policies. Prior to June this year there had been some amelioration of the policy by this government, but further reform is necessary to ensure that, while we protect our borders, we are humane and just to those affected by our policies and those who seek asylum here.

The latest package of reforms seeks to reconcile the governmentâs wish to maintain mandatory detention with the belief that refugees and asylum seekers can and should be treated with greater fairness, humanity, compassion and transparency. The detention arrangements legislation passed in June dealt with two areas of particular concern: the detention of children and families and the indefinite detention of asylum seekers without external scrutiny.

In that legislation, the parliament affirmed the principle that a child shall only be detained as a matter of last resort. It introduced a process to allow all children and their families to live in the community, free to attend school, day care, playgrounds and so on without security supervision. In June there were 59 children in immigration detention centres. All of these children and their families were out by the end of July, and I understand that no more were held in a centre, at least until earlier this month.

However, seven West Timorese asylum seekers arrived by boat in north-western Australia on 5 November. They were detained originally and flown to Darwin, then to Christmas Island, where they were placed in a detention centre which had been empty, had been closed and was reopened. This raises a number of questions for me, one being: why Christmas Island rather than on the mainland, where they had been initially placed? But, more pertinently here, those asylum seekers include two infant children. I believe one is a one-year-old child and the other is a two-year-old child. I have been advised that the children and their parents have now been placed in a house in the community. On the information provided to me, placing the children and their families in an immigration detention centre, albeit for a brief period of time, was not consistent with the June reforms, and I have conveyed that view to the government.

The second achievement of the June amendments was that the cases of people who have been held in immigration detention for two or more years will be independently scrutinised. The Commonwealth Ombudsman is charged with reviewing the cases of these long-term detainees, and the Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs must report to the Ombudsman on the status and case management of these people. The Ombudsman, Professor John McMillan, was given extensive powers to facilitate these investigations and the power to make recommendations that he considers appropriate.

The conduct of the immigration detention regime has lacked openness for far too long. One need only reflect briefly on the report by Mick Palmer on the detention of Cornelia Rau or on Neil Comrieâs investigation into the deportation of Vivian Alvarez to appreciate the incontrovertibility of this point. Mr Palmer found:

quote.para: ... a serious cultural problem within DIMIAâs immigration compliance and detention areas ... a culture that is overly self-protective and defensive ... unwilling to challenge organisational norms or to engage in genuine self-criticism or analysis.

speech.para: He found âserious problems with the handling of immigration detention casesâ stemming from âdeep-seated cultural and attitudinal problems within DIMIAâ. In discussing the deportation of Vivian Alvarez, the Palmer report found:

quote.para: ... events, practices and actions in 2003 and 2004 ... which strongly corroborate and confirm the systemic nature of the problems identified in the Cornelia Rau inquiry. An initial analysis of other cases ... shows that many of the same causal factors seem to be present.
The strong possibility that the same factors have contributed to the inappropriate detention of a number of other people over an extended period should give rise to serious concern.

speech.para: The Comrie inquiry similarly found:

quote.para: ... a flawed DIMIA cultureâone that pays insufficient attention to detaineesâ welfare and care needs.

speech.para: It found:

quote.para: DIMIA failed to meet its duty of care obligations to Vivian and unlawfully removed her from Australia.
... The unlawful removal of Vivian was a consequence of systemic failures in DIMIAâ

speech.para: and that:

quote.para: DIMIAâs overall management of Vivianâs case can only be described as catastrophic.

speech.para: Further, it found:

quote.para: The most disturbing feature of the culture is that senior officers in DIMIA who became aware that an Australian citizen had been unlawfully removed failed to take any action to redress the situation.

speech.para: I welcome the steps being taken to change the departmentâs culture, and I welcome the involvement of the Ombudsman in improving the transparency of the regime to the parliament and to the people of Australia.

A further important measure of the governmentâs package of reforms is embodied in this billâthat is, to finalise expeditiously applications by people who are seeking permanent protection. In June, the government committed DIMIA and the Refugee Review Tribunal to completing the processing of around 4,000 then pending TPV applicants by 31 October.

As I have said previously, given the history of administrative difficulties in the area of mandatory detention, one has to be highly sensitive about issues of implementation. The progress of the implementation of the governmentâs reform has been monitored. It has been assessed by the newly created immigration interdepartmental committee under the chairmanship of the Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The committee has met regularly since June, once a fortnight, and will continue to have a role as these reforms continue to be implemented. I, and other interested members of the governmentâin particular, the members for Cook, Pearce and McMillan, and Senator Troethâhave also been monitoring this. As foreshadowed, we have been meeting regularly with the chairman of the immigration interdepartmental committee to ensure that the reforms are being implemented satisfactorily. Generally, I am encouraged by the progress that I am advised has been achieved in the months since these measures were agreed.

As I have mentioned, the government in June committed to having around 4,000 applications for permanent protection by people with temporary protection visas processed by 31 October. The minister for immigration earlier this month announced that, of the actual figure of 3,400 applications in this category, the department had finalised all those within its power to complete. Permanent protection visas have now been issued to 2,871 applicantsâthat is, over 90 per cent of decided cases. Security and certainty have finally been restored to these people and they can begin to plan for family reunion.

There are still some 264 applications that cannot be finalised until security assessments by an outside agency are completed. As I said before, all children formerly in immigration detention and their families are now living in the community. In June this year, 149 detainees had been detained for more than two years. As of 27 October, of these 149 people, 102 have been released from immigration detention centres whether on a permanent or temporary protection visa or pending a bridging visa. Another five are awaiting security or character checks and 30 cases are with the minister or being prepared for submission to the minister. There is no doubt that progress is being made. However, much more remains to be done. The mental health status of many of the remaining detainees at Baxter and Villawood continues to decline, as is confirmed by independent psychiatric assessment. This remains a major concern.

We know what long-term detention means. Members from both sides, including my colleague the member for Canning, have visited immigration detention facilities. We have witnessed the impact of the terrible stress of living in an agony of uncertainty behind razor wire. The process of resolving the future of those who are still held in long-term detentionâfortunately a rapidly diminishing numberâmust continue and be accelerated. The review role of the Commonwealth Ombudsman is, I believe, critical in this process. At 27 October, the cases of 153 long-term detainees have been referred to the Ombudsman. This comprises 40 detainees who have reached the two-year mark since the end of June, as well as 113 of the detainees who already, at the end of June, had been in detention for two years or more.

The cases of all long-term detainees that existed at 17 June this year are to be referred to the Ombudsman before the end of the year. He has indicated that his office is prepared to consider appropriate information, including submissions from detaineesâ advocates and letters of support. The Ombudsman has set a maximum time frame of three months for providing an assessment of the case referred to by DIMIA but he does anticipate that most assessments will be finalised in much less than three months.

The governmentâs reforms are very substantial and further time will be required to implement them in full. I appreciate the efforts by Dr Peter Shergold, the Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and the immigration departmentâs secretary, Mr Andrew Metcalfe, in particular. Tribute is due to the non-government organisations that have gone to great lengths in a short time to provide practical requirements for the reforms to be implemented, including the provision of accommodation in the wider community.

As was foreshadowed in June, this bill comprises the second major legislative element in the governmentâs reform package. In addition to the reform measures, there are two further aspects of the bill. One deals with technical amendments. The second is more significant. It relates to an issue arising out of the Palmer report on the circumstances of the detention of Cornelia Rauânamely, the identification of people in immigration detention. Without going into that aspect of this bill in any detail, I will say that events have demonstrated the need for the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to take great care to confirm the identity of people it may subject to detention and to deportation.

This bill introduces time limits concerning decisions on protection visa applications at both the primary decision and at the Refugee Review Tribunal stages. Secondly, it contains measures that give effect to the Commonwealth Ombudsmanâs enhanced role as the Immigration Ombudsman. As a result of these amendments, the minister and the Refugee Review Tribunal will be required to make a decision or complete a review of a decision on a protection visa within 90 days. Any protection visa applications and review applications that take longer than the 90 days must be reported to the minister, and these reports on delayed decisions of reviews must state why the 90-day time limit has not been met. The explanatory memorandum gives examples of reasons why the time limit may not be met, including âcooperation by the applicant, security-checking processes and the provision of information by other governmentsâ. These reports must be tabled both in this place and in the Senate.

Since June, the number of primary protection visa applications on foot has been reduced from 983 to 564 as at the start of November. Of that number, 111 remain unresolved after more than 90 days, down from 402 in June. The number of cases awaiting review by the Refugee Review Tribunal has also declined. In short, progress has been madeâsignificant progress, I believeâbut more needs to be done to ensure that all the requirements of this bill are met. I have been advised that, since the governmentâs reforms were announced, the department has already begun to expedite protection visa applications to ensure that they do not take longer than 90 days to decide. This has lessened long-term cases, particularly those applications by people in detention. Similarly, I have been advised that the Refugee Review Tribunal has already been seeking to operate within the 90-day limit.

The length of time taken to resolve the applications of people seeking protection in Australia not only prolongs the applicantâs emotional and mental distress; it causes extra psychological concerns. One hopes these people get significant psychological relief from the knowledge that there is a limit on the time their application for a protection visa or a Refugee Review Tribunal review of their application will take to be decided and that, if the time is exceeded, their case will be open to external review.

The second element of the reform package contained in this bill is amendments to the Migration Act and to the Ombudsman Act that give effect to the Ombudsmanâs enhanced role as the Immigration Ombudsman. Together, these amendments, which have been outlined in the ministerâs second reading speech, will improve the Ombudsmanâs ability to review immigration and detention complaints and to conduct inquiries quickly and efficiently.

There are a number of other concerns about the fate of asylum seekers in Australia. A particular concernâwhich is arising more oftenâinvolves asylum seekers within the community who are denied access to both work rights and to Medicare or other health care support. Last week, the Minister for Health and Ageing announced a new Medicare item for comprehensive health checks for refugees and other humanitarian entrants within six months of arrival. I believe this is a commendable measure which goes some way towards recognising the particular health needs that asylum seekers and refugees have in addition to suffering the same health problems as the general population. The Australian Medical Association, to its great credit, has recently drawn attention to this. However, there do remain a significant number of asylum seekers living in the community who have no access to Medicare or to other health care supports and who need access to work rights.

Not all the measures that were originally proposed by us have been realised in the governmentâs reforms, and I do appreciate the comments made by the member for Kingsford Smith about the role of some of us on the government side. However, as I have described, substantial strides have been made in ensuring more flexible, humane, compassionate and accountable treatment for asylum seekers and others in the immigration system. The implementation of the reforms agreed by the Prime Minister has been commenced speedily and humanely. We look forward to the continuation and ultimate conclusion of these reforms in the near future. This bill continues the process of ensuring that immigration policies are administered with greater fairness, timeliness and transparency. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âIt is a pleasure to follow the member for Kooyong. I would like to congratulate him and his small band of colleagues for the work they have done and the role they have played in getting the Migration and Ombudsman Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 beforethe House today. This bill amends the Migration Act 1958 to do a number of things: to introduce 90-day processing time limits for the determination of protection visa applications and for the completion of reviews by the Refugee Review Tribunal; to permit disclosure of identifying information to individuals or the public to assist with identifying or locating a person who is otherwise unable to be identified or located; and to enable the Ombudsman to contact an immigration detainee where that person has not made a complaint to the Ombudsman.

speech.para: The bill also amends the Ombudsman Act 1976 to allow the Ombudsman to use the title âImmigration Ombudsmanâ when performing functions in relation to immigration and detention; to make it explicit that the Ombudsman can perform functions and exercise powers under other Commonwealth or ACT legislation; to enable an agency or person to provide information to the Ombudsman notwithstanding any law that would otherwise prevent them doing so; and to clarify that the actions of contractors and subcontractors in exercising powers or performing functions for or on behalf of Australian government agencies will be taken to be the actions of the relevant agency. This bill also makes some technical amendments to the Migration Act and the Migration Legislation Amendment Act (No. 1) 2001.

This bill is here today because of pressure on this government for changes to how we deal with and treat people who come to Australia seeking asylum from various unbearable or inhumane conditions in their own countries. Let us be very clear about the fact that this bill is not here because the government has any commitment to the principles upon which this bill is based. The bill is here because of community pressure, including pressure from the ALP. The final straw was pressure from a few government backbenchers who took the step of threatening to introduce their own bill to make changes to how we treat asylum seekers. I have already congratulated the member for Kooyong and should place on record my congratulations to him and to the members of that government backbench group.

The government has introduced this bill, has been forced into this action, because it had to do something to quieten down the debate. This bill represents the smallest price the government could pay and get some peace on the issue. But this peace will be short lived, because there is still a lot of work to be done and lots of improvements to be made in this area. Some of the changes still to be made are reflected in the amendments to this bill which were moved by the member for Watson. Those government members who finally threw their weight behind others who have been campaigning on these issues for a very long time should be proud of themselves for taking this action. But I do have to say that they were silent for a very long time and on a number of occasions in the last few years voted against Labor motions trying to do the very things that they eventually put forward. Their action was initiated and was successful because of the sustained campaigning of many people throughout Australia. This is an example of what persistence can achieve. Let us just hope we do not have to wait as long as we have done to get more desperately needed changes made.

The ALP have been arguing for some time now for the removal of children from detention and for a faster and more transparent system of processing protection visas. Laborâs policy at the last election was for a system whereby 90 per cent of protection visa applications would be processed in 90 days. Our policy established an ombudsman to report on people detained for more than 90 days and on a monthly basis thereafter. We have been arguing for an independent inspector-general of detention to monitor conditions and resolve complaints; for a guarantee of independent medical and media access to detention centres; and for detention centres to be managed by Commonwealth officers on Commonwealth territory.

The bill here today and the previous bill go some way towards these policies, but not far enough. In more recent times we have seen a series of incidents which point to appalling incompetence and indifference within the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. We have seen Cornelia Rau, a mentally ill Australian citizen detained for months in a detention centre. We have seen Vivian Alvarez Solon, the victim of a car accident and also an Australian citizen, deported overseasâluckily into the hands of a caring hospice but left there to die by this government. Once she was foundâdue more to the efforts of her former husband than anything elseâshe was subjected to months of negotiations with this government about the conditions of her return to her home country.

Now we see Robert Jovicic, who has lived in Australia for almost all of his life, deported to Serbia because he has committed crimes here in Australia. This deportation took place in June 2004. I understand that Mr Jovicicâs parents are Serbian but Mr Jovicic was not born there, does not speak the language and is now stateless and destitute and sleeping on the steps of the Australian Embassy in Serbia. The minister has the authority to cancel the visa of a noncitizen found guilty of a crime which leads to a lengthy prison sentence. This law has now been used to deport a person who is, in all ways except formally, an Australian.

It is just too easy to use this law to remove a problem which is common enough in Australia. There are many people living on our streets who suffer from psychiatric illnesses and who are drug users. Many of these people end up in prison. Deporting one such person, because someone found a means of doing so, does not address this problem in our society.

All these incidents demonstrate a department which has developed a culture of suspicion and a marked lack of any humanity or regard for people. I put the blame for this development squarely in the lap of this minister and her predecessor. I am sure there are many good and decent public servants in the department, but they are forced to respond to a culture pushed down on them from above.
The shadow minister for immigration, the member for Watson, has moved an amendment to this bill which addresses this point.Â It reads:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

item.para: notes that, for the Bill to be effective in delivering more humane treatment of detainees, it is essential that the culture within the Department of Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs needs to change;

recognises that the independent reports produced by Mr Mick Palmer AO APM and by the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Prof. John McMillan, of an inquiry undertaken by Mr Neil Comrie AO APM, each conclude that the cultural problems became entrenched in the years leading up to 2001;
condemns the refusal by the then Minister for Immigration and current Attorney-General to take responsibility for that culture;
condemns the refusal by the current Minister for Immigration to take responsibility for the continuation of that culture;
agrees with the finding of Mr Palmerâs report that âReform must come from the topâ and therefore calls on the Prime Minister to dismiss the Attorney General and the Minister for Immigration;
calls on the Government to take action to terminate the contracts which outsource the management of detention centres to Global Solutions Ltd; and
calls on the Government to return the management of detention centres to the Commonwealth and locate all detention centres on Commonwealth Territoryâ.

speech.para: I thoroughly support this amendment. Another area that the government continues to ignore is the plight of temporary protection visa and bridging visa holders. Whilst the bill here today addresses the issue of timely processing of claims, it does not help the thousands of TPV and bridging visa holders who are left to drift through our society with no support or certainty of their future.

The Asylum Seeker Project, ASP, based at Melbourneâs Hotham Mission has identified countless cases of human beings falling through the enormous cracks in this system. The ASP is one of those groups that have taken up the responsibility of caring for community based asylum seekers while the government turns its back, and those involved in that project know what they are talking about. A study of theirs goes some way to illustrating the huge problems that remain in the system, despite the changes we are examining here.

The Asylum Seeker Project study of 200 community based asylum seekers found that 95 per cent had no work rights or Medicare benefits; 68 per cent were homeless or at risk of homelessness; 44 per cent were in debt to friends, lawyers or had outstanding bills or detention costs; and 24 per cent were refused medical treatment because of their asylum seeker status. In light of those facts, can anyone here sincerely claim that the problems of the immigration system are being fixed? The ALP has committed itself to ensuring asylum seekers and refugees in the Australian community have appropriate health and income support.Â They need to be allowed to work. We need to remove the burden of support for asylum seekers from the states, welfare organisations and churches.

Where is the government on these issuesâwhere is its response to the ongoing suffering and hardship of these human beings? Since July 1997 all asylum seekers who apply for a protection visa after 45 days of arriving are denied the right to work. Those who apply within 45 days lose their work rights if they make a request to the minister to intervene under section 417 of the Migration Act.

Asylum seekers living in the community do not want charity, nor do they want to be reliant on welfare. They simply want the right to earn a living, support their families and contribute to the Australian economy while their application is being processed. Many asylum seekers bring with them skills and experiences that are in short supply in Australia. A recent skills audit of a sample of work rights in eligible asylum seekers in Victoria found that 71 per cent of those surveyed had qualifications or skills that matched those listed on the skills occupations list for the general skills migration scheme. The audit also revealed qualified accountants, auto-electricians, chefs, hairdressers and nurses as well as a number of other professions and trades that are listed on that scheme. This is at a time when the government has increased the skilled migration intake by 20,000 people in an attempt to address Australiaâs skills shortages. TPV and bridging visa holders need to be allowed to work. They need access to good health care and the dignity that goes with all of this.

Finally, I want to talk about how our detention centres are managed.Â Earlier this year the ANAOâthe Australian National Audit Officeâissued an audit report into the management of detention centres. The ANAO reported that DIMIA had a contract with GSL for the provision of services to people in detention. This contract is worth about $100 million per year. I should precede my remarks by noting that this government sells itself to the electorate as a good economic manager, but that claim is not supported by this report. The ANAO has found that the contracting out of the management of the detention centres is not being well managed. The government, which claims to be a good economic manager, cannot manage to put together a decent contract or establish how the performance of this contract is to be measured. The ANAO reports:

quote.para: â¦ the Contract does not establish clear expectations for the level and quality of services to be delivered; mechanisms to protect the Commonwealthâs interests are not clear; and there is insufficient information about the quality of services being delivered and their costs to allow a value-for-money calculation.

speech.para: The ANAO also reports:

quote.para: â¦ DIMIA has put in place 148 standards, 243 measures and more than 300 descriptions of detention services with, up until January 2005, equal emphasis on each one. Assessing the performance of GSL would be more straightforward if these standards were risk based, better defined and more easily measured.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

DIMIAâs monitoring of GSLâs performance focuses on Incidents (with considerable discretion on reporting and what is an Incident) and, as a consequence, DIMIA is not able to provide assurance that all its standards are being met as expected.

speech.para: The ANAO found:

quote.para: An important element of the accountability framework in managing contracts on behalf of the Commonwealth is to ensure that the interests of the Commonwealth are protected as far as possible. The ANAO concluded that the terms of the liability, indemnity and insurance regime in the Contract are unclear to the point that it is not possible for the Commonwealth to know with any certainty what insurances are effected, what risks are covered, and to what extent the insurance cover that has been obtained is limited or qualified.

speech.para: The ANAO said:

quote.para: Although DIMIA has publicly stated the need to report on âefficientâ detention, the cost and productivity data available indicate that contract administration costs have risen appreciably over the life of the Contract, against a falling detainee population. However, DIMIA does not have sufficient relevant and credible information about the quality of services being delivered and their costs, to determine whether the delivery of detention services is improving over time, or other factors are resulting in increased costs.

speech.para: In other words, the contract with GSL is not clear about how performance is to be measured, it has been left to GSL to determine when an incident should be reported, the protection of Commonwealth assets is not properly managed, and curiously the costs of providing these services has increased despite a falling population in the detention centres and no-one can say why this is so.

In summary, the measures in this bill are welcome, but they do not go anyway near far enough in addressing the endemic problems within the department of immigration or in addressing the shortfalls in the way we process applications from those seeking asylum in this country or how we look after them during that process. The new measures are a step in the right direction, and for that reason I welcome them. But I remind members on both sides of the House that so much more is left to be done. This bill may have silenced some critics for the moment, but decency has not been satisfied and much more work needs to be done.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr JOHN COBB

talk.start.para: âI would like to thank the members for their contributions to the Migration and Ombudsman Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the opposition and the minor parties for supporting it, and I remind the House that this is a necessary step in the continuing development and improvement of migration law and administration in Australia.

speech.para: The bill will improve the speed and transparency of protection visa decision making by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and the Refugee Review Tribunal. It will ensure a greater level of accountability and explanation of the protection visa determination process, assist the Ombudsman to handle immigration and detention complaints and inquiries swiftly and efficiently, and allow immigration officers to better identify or locate persons in connection with the administration of the act by finetuning important protections given to the release of personal identifiers, which has been something of a problem in recent cases.

The amendments generally build on reforms to immigration detention arrangements announced by the Prime Minister in June this year and other arrangements that the government has introduced in recent times. Specifically, the bill provides a 90-day time limit for decision on all primary protection visa applications and any subsequent Refugee Review Tribunal review of such decisions. This time limit has been introduced in line with the Prime Ministerâs announcement to ensure that applications are finalised in a prompt and transparent manner; however, the time limits will not operate to the disadvantage of applicants.

Departmental officers and RRT members will continue to be obliged to make fair decisions in a manner that gives applicants a clear opportunity to present their case. Where these time limits have not been met, the bill requires that periodic reports will be provided to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs by the secretary and principal members of the RRT on the reasons why these time limits were not met, including factors outside the control of the department and the tribunal. Those reports will be tabled by the minister in parliament. The reports will provide additional assurance to the parliament and the public that protection visa and review applications are dealt with in a timely manner.

On 14 July this year, the government announced that the Ombudsman would be given an enhanced role as the Immigration Ombudsman. The bill will enable the Ombudsman, when investigating matters of immigration and detention, to call himself or herself the Immigration Ombudsman.

The bill contains a range of provisions to support and facilitate the Ombudsman in dealing with immigration and detention complaints and inquiries as expeditiously as possible. For example, the bill will facilitate the early provision of information to the Ombudsman by providing that disclosure of information to the Ombudsman during a preliminary inquiry or investigation will be taken to be authorised by law for the purposes of the Privacy Act and not prevented by any other Commonwealth enactment.

Amendments also provide that action by Commonwealth contractors and subcontractors in the exercise of a power or the performance of a function for or on behalf of an agency will be taken for the purpose of the Ombudsman Act to be action by the agency where the contract is for the provision of goods or services to the public.

The bill repeals the current provision in the Migration Act 1958 that excludes immigration detainees who have not made a complaint to the Ombudsman from the entitlement which would otherwise apply to receive mail from the Ombudsman. This will enable the Ombudsman to contact immigration detainees at his or her own initiative.

The finetuning that has been done in relation to the release of personal identifiers is part of the governmentâs response to the recommendation of the inquiry into the circumstances of the immigration detention of Cornelia Rau. One of the concerns of the inquiry was that DIMIA had been reluctant to publicly release photographs of Ms Rau during the departmentâs efforts to identify her. The bill provides power for this type of disclosure and generally strengthens the ability of migration officers to perform their functions under the Migration Act.

The bill contains proposed technical amendments which are consequential to the commencement of provisions contained in the Legislative Instruments Act 2003, which commenced on 1 January 2005. These technical amendments are necessary to preserve the operation of various migration legislation provisions following the commencement of the Legislative Instruments Act. The provisions have to date been preserved by transitional regulations. As well as preserving the operation of numerous migration legislation provisions, this bill ensures that migration legislation is consistent with the new legal and procedural framework created by the Legislative Instruments Act.
During the second reading debate some points were raised. The honourable member for Watson referred to a 90-day period and said:

quote.para: There is a good reason why we want the 90-day rule that is in this bill ... mandatory detention should not mean indefinite detention.

speech.para: The member appears to have been referring to the oppositionâs policy that immigration detention be reviewed after 90 days. He then went on to attribute the initiatives of the bill to the Labor Party. I draw to the attention of the House and the honourable member to the fact that the amendments in this bill relate to the processing times for protection visa applications. They relate to all protection visa applicants. These amendments are not about detention, nor do they only apply to protection visa applicants in detention. I draw the honourable member for Watsonâs attention to the fact that over 95 per cent of persons currently seeking a primary decision on their protection visa applications are in the community; they are not in immigration detention.

The member for Watson also raised the conclusions of Mr Palmer and Mr Comrie that there have been cultural problems within the immigration department. This government is committing $230 million over the next five years to address many issues raised by the Commonwealth Ombudsmanâs report, including the establishment of a college of immigration, border security and compliance to deliver comprehensive operational training for DIMIA officers; and the establishment of a 12-month pilot program to develop a holistic community care model to improve the health and the wellbeing of detainees.

The government will also be boosting funding to immediately address IT deficiencies identified by Mr Palmer in the areas of border control, compliance and detention management systems; for the establishment of a new client services division within the department to drive a client service culture and systems throughout it; and for the Commonwealth Ombudsman to fulfil his enhanced role as Immigration Ombudsman, as spelt out in this bill, as well as expanding his powers in examining detention and compliance activities.

This bill contains important and necessary initiatives. It is a reflection of our governmentâs commitment to be transparent and accountable. On behalf of the government I thank all those involved in the passage of this bill.
Question agreed to.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: EUROPEAN BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Pearce:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe tumbling of the Berlin Wall and the crumbling of the former communist regimes of eastern Europe had enormous consequences for those of us living in Western democracies. New markets were opened up to us and enormous economic opportunities flowed and continue to flow. But those of us living in Western democracies can hope to have only a small idea of the consequences of the lowering of the Iron Curtain for many central eastern Europe states and even some western Asian states. In 1991 the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development was established to help these countries through the transition to democracy and the concept of free market economies. The bank uses tools of investment to assist countries, currently numbering 27, from central Europe to parts of Asia. On 30 January 2004 the bankâs board of governors unanimously voted to admit Mongolia into its sphere of operation. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Amendment Bill 2005 amends article 1 of the agreement establishing the bank to allow Mongoliaâs entry. On that basis the opposition supports the bill.

speech.para: Australiaâs commitment to supporting our European friends, and, indeed, our struggling friends in parts of Asia, is an important one in both moral and economic terms. It is no secret that, taken as a whole, Europe is lagging behind the rest of the world both in unemployment and in the pace of economic growth. There are many challenges for the European Union and the broader international economy in helping to modernise the economies of many of the former Eastern bloc countries, and the bank plays an important role in this regard. The opposition values our economic relations with Europe. Taken as a whole, the EU is Australiaâs largest economic partner when taking into account two-way trade in goods and services, investment and transfers. While Australia runs a considerable trade imbalance with the EUâsomething we all hope will improveâit is nevertheless an important market. Trade is in many ways better balanced than other markets, owing to better diversification of merchandise and service trade. Services trade with the EU is Australiaâs largest export market, an area that is crucial for us to grow further. Also, despite the subsidies of European primary producers, Australian exports of food have grown almost 140 per cent in the last eight years.

Conflict over agricultural subsidies in the EU has dominated market access issues in Australian EU multilateral trade negotiations more generally. Reform of these subsidies and other regulatory issues has been making glacial progress, and few would disagree that reform needs to be hastened. Hastening economic reforms in Europe in developed and developing economies alike will be of mutual benefit to EU and non-EU countries alike. It is a two-way street. We gladly and enthusiastically participate in granting assistance to our friends in other nations, including those in the old Eastern bloc, but as a country we do expect the game to be played very fairly and these forms of assistance to be reciprocated in kind. But this bill is eminently supportableâMongoliaâs entry into the bankâs sphere of influence and operations is obviously important to that countryâand on that basis the opposition is happy to lend its support.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Amendment Bill 2005 and the provision of the legislative impetus to add Mongolia as the 28th member of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the EBRD. The work of the EBRD obviously has its historic origins in 1991. Many of the Bretton Woods institutions and international bodies were formed out of the optimism of a post-conflict environment, and that was no different with the collapse of the Soviet empire and the many states that had puppet communist governments. There was, of course, a power vacuum and a need to transition rapidly into a more financially liberalised international economy. There was also some belief that the EC were not fully prepared to fill that role, given their strategic and geographic location, and that was why it was important to set up a body like the EBRD.

speech.para: Looking back now and having the benefit of 15 years to look at their achievements, we can see that it has not been without criticism, and I would like to reflect a little on that but also point out that the addition of Mongolia is an important extension. It geopolitically moves the bankâs role, as we see with the African, Latin American and Asian development banks, right across the Asian region, and there is no more worthy a new entrant to the sphere of influence of the EBRD than Mongolia, given its landlocked location between two great superpowers. Of course, Mongolia itself has an economic history that is of great interest to Australia. Once referred to somewhat disparagingly as the 16th Soviet republic for its strong links to Russia, Mongolia managed to foster very early diplomatic links with about 50 countries, even while it was closely linked to Russia. But I think that what we have seen over the last 20 years has been a real reorientation towards the rest of the world, an effort to open up, and that is what makes Mongolia a perfect additional candidate to join the ranks of the EBRD.

That history goes back, I think, to the thawing of Sino-Mongolian relationships in the mid-1980s. We see now what have been important trade links, a real reorientation in exportation. Fifty per cent of all Mongoliaâs exports now are to China and only about four per cent are to Russia. We have seen agreements enabling Mongolia to export their produce directly out of a Chinese port. We have seen them turning to international bodies. There were early links with the IMF in 1991 and with the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development, part of the World Bank group, soon after that, in 1996. We saw them joining up with ASEAN, we saw the ascension to the WTO in 1996 and now, obviously, they are looking towards APEC.

In many respects, Mongolia had a faltering beginning. In 1991 it first started to reopen its monasteries and churches. There were over 100 independent newspapers and news outletsâindependent of government. But also there was a sort of re-evolution of the national consciousness in Mongolia. There had almost been a sense that they did not want to talk about their history while they had that relationship with that larger Soviet neighbour to the north.

In Mongolia we have now seen rapid population growth; with that come needs for development. There may well be just one person per 1.6 kilometres. They have many economic virtues that are yet to be fully exploited. Like Australia, in many cases they are quite isolated. They are exporting copper and gold. They have many other minerals yet to be fully assessed. They have a burgeoning but small manufacturing and food processing industry.
