They are all areas where Australia can make a contribution but, more importantly, and pertinent to this bill, they provide every reason for Mongolia to enjoy the benefits that the EBRD can offer.

Before I talk about some of the criticisms that have been levelled at the EBRD, it is important to note that it has made massive steps in the last few years in response to some of those criticisms. Early on, there was some Anglo-Saxon scepticism about the work of the EBRD and whether it was geographically centred too much on the caucuses and eastern Europe. The bank has answered that criticism. It has spread and it has evolved. Keep in mind that in many cases it picked up its early work from very moribund economies. It was not operating in a monopoly environment; there were other banks competing for that attention as well. It was operating in situations where there were low levels of confidence, certainly in the private sectorâin areas where the private sector was not yet willing to stand alone and take chances on small- to medium-sized enterprises and not willing to take a chance with soft loans. Obviously, as with all international banks, the donor countries to the EBRD have some concerns about returns. Then there is the overhanging concern for any international banking organisation: that their disbursements can keep up with their commitments. Last year there were â¬4.1 billion worth of commitments, and disbursements of about â¬3.4 billion. EBRD has done something about that, and that is not a bad achievement.

If we look cumulatively at their achievements, $28 billion has been lent over their history. They have managed to attract $US52 billion from other sources, for a total of around $78 billion. That is an impressive achievement itself and it is a sign of the confidence of those private-public relationships.

I want to say just a few words about what is unique about the EBRD in the context of Mongoliaâs joining. The EBRD was the first of the international institutions to write into its goals a focus on environmental sustainability. That should be recognised. The World Bank group, in its quality assurance group work, was always looking at environmental implications for its lending, but never before had a bank specifically written that into its goals. That should be acknowledged. Also it had a focus on democracy and governance. It had a focus not just on the corporate sector or individual businesses but on moving the country towards a more democratic frontierâand in many cases it has been successful.

It is worth noting that in April last year the EBRD took the very bold step of saying, âNo, weâre not going to lend to Uzbekistan. Thereâs been a democratic compact that youâve failed on. Youâve failed to develop civic society. Weâve given you a series of goals in public policy that youâve either flouted or failed to achieve.â For an international bank to say that they are withdrawing from that frontier, after sustained criticism from the NGO sector, is an achievement. I applaud them for that. They did not persist where it was completely impossible in a completely hostile governance arrangement. They said âenough is enoughâ and they withdrew. That was a very important signal to the rest of the world and to other banking institutions that, if countries are not working towards a more democratic system, one that benefits the entire population, they can say no.

Today the EBRDâs work is already well developed in central Europe. They already have substantial loans to and projects in Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. That makes Mongolia a logical extension of, and probably completes the extension towards, the APEC rim. As I say, adding Mongolia is the right step to take. The reason we are proposing the changes in the bill today is that part of the requirement of the EBRD is that a legislative change is made to give that membership the impetus in all of its member nations. I think there are almost 50 of them, plus two intergovernmental groups, that effectively are the creditor nations to the EBRD.

The EBRDâs work has changed over the last few years. These changes will benefit Mongolia. There has been a shift away from the dimeric relationship of merchant banking and development assistance. That was something that was unique about the EBRD. They tried to run a very strong merchant banking arm. I know that the member for Wentworth may touch on that in his contribution. But we have found that the private banking sector can do it better. In response to that, the EBRD has very much downsized and de-emphasised the merchant banking role.

The great benefit of that dimeric relationship when it was conceived was that there would be a real sense of developmental economics woven into the merchant banking work but there would also be a real sense of corporate awareness and a focus on return in their development assistance work, which has often been lacking in some international investment. That was the dream anyway.

The criticism in the 1990s was that information for ordinary citizens about the work of the EBRD in their own country was insufficient. The EBRD responded, in 2000 I think, with their public information policy, their PIP. Some would say that that has not gone far enough. You can see this tension in the work of any funding body or developmental organisation: how do you ensure that the rights and the views of every citizen are considered, particularly when you are a bank working with, say, the corporate sector?

In response to that, moving the corporate sector to a more privatised, entrepreneurial and responsive system to internationalise financial flows was one step in the early 1990s. Now we have seen the shift that I believe the EBRD had to make. It has moved to small to medium enterprises and a real focus on working on the ground, having lots of bankers working in the field rather than in large headquarters. They are all positive indications that the EBRD is evolving, that it is looking to what we call early transition economies, that it is shifting its lending away from some of the recent EU membership and some of the more successful and more completely transitioned economies to the newer, poorer economies. That is also a great sign of responsiveness.

The year 2004 was a tumultuous one for that institution. Look at eastern Europe and central Asia. Never has the connection between politics and economy been more fully exemplified. In early 2004 we saw the early election results in Georgia, where a population stood up and said, âThat is not good enough.â Those people forced a new election.

At the end of 2004 in the Ukraine we saw the run-off elections that were effectively contaminated by corruption. The standoff between Yanukovich and Yushchenko resulted in the re-run-off election on 26 December. I was privileged enough to be an election observer for that. At that time and during the orange revolution, the huge optimism in that economy for a new, more transparent and more democratic process was held high. I have to make a note that, when we look back over 12 months, it has been a very rocky year for that nation.

Mongolia will now benefit from some of the advantages of the EBRD, but it is important to contain some of the optimism that there will be massive changes. In 2004 we saw a very close fought election in Mongolia and a return to the MPRP, which was the original government during Soviet times. There has been a full circle move there in a political sense and elections will be held again in 2008. While it was a knife-edge result in that election, we hope for four years of stability to start to bed down some of the opportunities in Mongolia. Let us talk about those.

For Australia, our import-export relationship is, I think it would be fair to say, fairly underdeveloped. We are about 44th in the ranking of trade, in both imports and exports. The main exports to Mongolia have been primarily mining and exploratory equipment to do survey work there. There are enormous opportunities, as there are for many nations in the region. The arrival of the EBRD gives a chance to some projects that are beyond the aid giving of Australiaâwhich, I should note, has increased tenfold in 15 years, from $300,000 to $2.9 million. It gives many opportunities for some of the larger infrastructure work to provide the platform from which Australian aid can benefit. That is important to remember. It is often very difficult for a country to come in with free and stand-alone programs, particularly in a country where we do not have a major international relations focus. With the EBRD arriving as an additional donor and Mongolia being eligible for those funds, our efforts in international aid and development can only benefit.

A good point to conclude on is that the arrival of Mongolia as a new member of the EBRD may not have enormous strategic significance to Australia, but on the plus side of the equation is the responsiveness of the EBRD. I think it is evolving to meet the needs of the area, as we see the ripple effect from Central Asia and the expansion of the EU. Mongolia is the right country to benefit from it and is possibly, in that sense of geographic expansion, the last of the states to be added to the EBRD.

We see opportunities for Australia to expand its importation and exportation balance. We have already seen a visit in April this year by the Speaker, the members for Herbert and Fisher and a number of others from the other side of the chamberâan important step in our links with Mongolia. We have also seen earlier visits, both from the Mongolian side, which has its diplomatic mission based in Beijing, and from Chris Gallus, the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

I am optimistic about where we are going with our relationship with Mongolia. Mongolia has certainly been outward focused, and that is a good thing. It has worked very hard on the democratic and participatory, governance based institutions that make it a more promising location to invest. For those reasons, in addition to the presence already of the World Bank Group, which is not insubstantial, I welcome the addition of Mongolia to the EBRD. I support this bill, which gives the legislative impetus. I look forward to a strengthened relationship between Australia and Mongolia in the future.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Causley, beyond the normal thanks I thank you for coming up beyond your normal responsibilities to chair the chamber so that I would be free to speak, and I am very grateful for that; thank you very much. I am not sure everybody else will be grateful, but I am! I, of course, will be supporting the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Amendment Bill 2005, because I concur with the view that, if the EBRD wishes to extend its services to Mongolia, we as a participating member should support that. It is a minor issue for the EBRD but a major issue for Mongolia, and there is no reason why we should not be positive about that.

speech.para: I want to raise a few queries about the broader question of Australiaâs participation in the EBRD. I do that explicitly accepting that I was one of the ministers who actively advocated Australiaâs original membership. As the trade minister at the time, I examined the question and felt that, although it was a fairly marginal case, on balance Australia should participate. A lot of people have said that Australia should participate in this bank as a good international citizen participating in international institutions doing positive things. I have to say that that is a principle fairly selectively applied, because there are other international development banks in areas of greater need in which Australia does not participate. I do not particularly advocate our participation in those; I simply note that we have to be careful about Eurocentric double standards where we think we should be enthusiastically helping moderately well-off countries in a very important transition to democracyâwhich I absolutely welcome and am happy to give assistance toâbut where we decline to participate in helping the poorest countries try to make their transition out of poverty.

The fact that this is unquestionably, on the part of the international community, an institution set up with good intentions is not of itself sufficient to justify our continuing participation. While it was a part of our original decision, and a welcome partâI certainly do not apologise for it; I think it is a positive elementâwhat tipped the balance, particularly for me then as trade minister but for the government of the day, were the hope and expectation that participation in the EBRD would enhance the possibility of Australian companies participating in the development work that would flow from the re-emerging market economies of Eastern Europe.

I have to say that, while I support this bill and I hope it brings significant assistance to Mongolia, it represents a very substantial eastward creep beyond the original expectation of what the EBRD would cover. Australia is an active participant in the Asian Development Bank, and I am a bit puzzled about why that bank is not actually a significantly more appropriate institution to play a major role in Mongolia. That is no reason for us to quibble about the EBRD wanting to provide assistance there, but I do think it is a little odd. I do not think countries are assisted by a proliferation of institutions assisting within their territory. The World Bank Group is there, and I think the ADB would be more appropriate there than the EBRD.

But I have no problem with the bill. Mongolia has made this application and the EBRD has given it a positive response, and we should support that. For so long as we are members of the EBRD, we should be responsible members, and a responsible member should support this propositionâand this parliament should pass this legislation. In any event, quite properly, the Treasurer has made a commitment on behalf of Australia that we will do this and the parliament should honour that commitmentâand I actually agree with what the Treasurer has done. Once the bank received the request, it was the appropriate thing to give it a positive response.

But I do have questions I want to ask. First, has there been a review of the benefits to Australian companies flowing from the decision to participate in the EBRD? I am not aware of one. I have seen no evidence of one, and I see very little evidence that any benefit has flowed. I am not as positive as the member for Bowman about the EBRDâs history and role in the area. There has been a significant economic transformation and a positive, if more modest, political transformation in the countries of the region, and it is probable that the EBRD has made a net positive contribution to that. I am not as sure that the original conception, which I supported at the time, was correct. Nevertheless, the body exists.

I would like to see what review has been done of the benefits which have flowed to Australian companies from participation, because, while there is no ongoing annual cost to the Australian budget under the current funding of the EBRDâsomething I want to raise a question about in a momentâAustralia has approximately $90 million of capital tied up in the EBRD. Is that money delivering benefits to Australian companies by facilitating their effective participation in the programs of the EBRD? I am extremely dubious about whether it is but, if there has been a review that says it is, I would like to see the outcome. In the great scheme of the Commonwealth budget $90 million is not very much moneyâand it is not something that could fund ongoing recurrent expenditure, because it is a capital itemâbut I think there is a case for asking whether this $90 million could be better used in the interests of Australian citizens and taxpayers.

I would note in passing that our participation in the EBRD has created, to the best of my knowledge, only one job for Australians. That is the job of director, which has been successively held under this government by failed former ministers. One I regard as a very decent human being is Jim Short, a former senator who was very unlucky to lose his portfolio as a result of a technical breachâin the times when there were ministerial standards in this government. He was called upon to resign. I think that was probably a correct decision, but I do not think he did anything major or grievous and I did not really object to his being sent to do the job at the EBRD as a consequence. However, the fact that former Minister Reith has wound up in this cushy sinecure is, in my view, an outrage, although I do not think that that is sufficient reason for us to withdraw from the EBRD. It is what I would call an incidental benefit.

However, I am seriously concerned as to whether we are appropriately allocating our international effort and interest by continuing to have a full-time director at the EBRD and by continuing to have our capital wrapped up there when we could perhaps use that to make a more effective contribution in the area of our primary interest in the Asia-Pacific region or in areas where need is greater or when we could apply that capital to domestic purposes, for which there are many alternative and better demands.

I do not know who is going to sum up on this bill on behalf of the government, but I noticed earlierâand I still think it is the caseâthat there were no Treasury people here taking notes. That is an inappropriate situation, if that is the case. It is an oversight that should not be allowed to continue. I am advised that the procedure flowing from the passage of the second reading of this bill is that a not uncommon statement will be made that the Governor-General has approved an appropriation for the purpose of this bill and that the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum says that this bill will have no significant financial impact. I cannot understand why it will have any, and I would like an explanation of why it will have some. If it is the case that it involves some minor increase in our capital, that would not lead me to oppose the bill, because it will be minor, but I would like to know. There is nothing in the ministerâs speech or in the explanatory memorandum to say so, and there is nothing on the face of my understanding of the nature of our commercial and contractual relationship with the EBRD to explain why there should be any appropriation for the purposes of this bill, and I would like an explanation of why that is so.

Notwithstanding that I have those major queries about our long-term association with the EBRD, so long as we are a member I certainly support the fact that we should be a responsible, positive member and that we should honour the governmentâs commitment and support the introduction of Mongolia. As the member for Bowman said, Mongolia is a participant in our region. It is a country that we have had the honour of effectively representing at the World Bank and the IMF. I have had that honour myself, and I have met with senior officials from Mongolia during the course of that process. We do have a small but positive relationship with Mongolia, which should be enhanced and developed over time. For all those reasons, I support the bill but I do call for a review of our long-term association with the EBRD.

talk.start.para: âLike the previous speakers, I, too, support the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Amendment Bill 2005. I think Mongolia is a very appropriate addition to the ranks of countries that the EBRD will support and assist. In effect, Mongolia was a client state of the Soviet Union for most of the last century and, as a consequence, most of its institutions were derived from Soviet models. The experience that the EBRD has had in investing and promoting economic reform in the former Soviet Union and its various satellites will stand it in very good stead with Mongolia. Notwithstanding its proximity to China and its long historical association with China, Mongolia had, in its governmental and political structure prior to its democratisation, much more of a Russian, or Soviet, feel about it than a Chinese one.

speech.para: The member for Fraser questioned Australiaâs involvement with the EBRD, I think in part because he wondered whether the support that we give the EBRDâwhich is not enormous, as we all knowâwould be better devoted to other, poorer, countries. While there are some relatively prosperous countries in the ranks of the EBRDâs clientsâin particular, I am talking about the eight countries that joined the European Union last year: Slovenia, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Poland and Hungary, the so-called EU8âthey, together with Croatia, represent, by any measure, countries that are moving dynamically down the road to prosperity.

The criticismâthis is the most substantive criticism that has been made of the EBRD in recent yearsâhas been that it should cease operating in those countries because its work is done. It should, for example, close its office in Ljubljana in Sloveniaâa country which is prospering so well, in large measure due to the EBRDâs efforts and of course the lure of EU accessionâand take those resources and move them further east. Last year, for example, of the â¬4 billion invested by the EBRD, just under â¬1 billion of thatââ¬960 millionâwas invested in these advanced countries, the EU8 plus Croatia. By comparison, only â¬316 million was invested in central Asia, which is the poorest part of the EBRDâs client base. Of that â¬316 million, â¬246 million was invested in one countryâKazakhstan. I mentioned earlier the differences in terms of poverty across the EBRDâs clients. In Tajikistan for example, 70 per cent of the population is living in poverty. By any measure, that is a very poor country.

The fundamental problem that all of these countries faced when they emerged from communism was a lack of law. As the member for Fraser would recall, in the early 1990s I spent a lot of time working on investment projects, mostly in the mining sector, in emerging post-communist countries, in particular Russia, and also Chinaâif you describe China as a post-communist countryâwhere I recall meeting the member for Fraser at a conference in Dalian more than 10 years ago.

When I was working in Russia on a large mining project in the early nineties, shortly after the fall of communism, the fundamental legal problem was that there was no legal system. All of these communist countries had on paper very elaborate legal systems, with courts and appeals and constitutions and regulations and so forth, but they had never been applied other than in a theoretical and cosmetic way. All of those countries, the Soviet Union in particular, had been run as command economies, and insofar as there was a legal process or a facsimile of a legal process it was run through the organs of the Communist Party. Once the Communist Party collapsed, there was in effect no legal system left.

The former communist countries in central Europe had a distinct memory of the rule of law and of civil institutions and were able to recreate them much more quickly than the countries further east, many of which had had no experience in their history of democracy or of the rule of law in the way that we understand it. Initially the EBRDâwhile it was set up to achieve political goals; that is to say, the development of democracy, rule of law, free markets and so forthâwas obliged to operate as a commercial bank. Indeed, for most of its life it has been a profitable bank. It had a very bad year following the Russian bond collapse in 1998, but since then it has been doing well. With that requirement that it actually operate commercially and profitably, it was inevitable that the bulk of its investment in the early decades was going to be in those countries that progressed most quickly to legal systems and political systems that were conducive to investment.

Basically what investors needâand this is particularly so in the resources sectorâis the confidence of knowing that the laws will be enforced and upheld, that their investment will not be expropriated and that they will not be stood over and have bribes demanded of them at any point, let alone at some indeterminate point in the future. So certainty, reliability and integrity are absolutely key. That is why, when we talk about foreign aid and the alleviation of poverty around the world, the Australian government is right in focusing its aid efforts on improving governance. Invariably, countries that are well governed and that have a system of democracy that works or a rule of law that is maintained will be able, all other things being equal, to develop a prosperous society where there are opportunities for all.

But that change of culture is an enormous one, and I will give you an example. I remember that in 1993 or 1994 I met with a senior politician in the Duma in Moscow to talk about some legislation they were passing which would have had an impact on the project with which I was involved.

talk.start.para: âOver vodka?

âThe member for Bowman has asked me whether it was about vodka. It may well have been inspired by some vodka, but it was in fact about natural resources. This senior politician planned to run for president, and he said, âWhen I am president, I will have Yeltsin shot.â I said: âReally? Has it occurred to you that, if you keep expressing this intention of having your political opponent shot, he will make it impossible for you ever to win an election?â We had this long conversation in which I pointed out to him that one of the merits of the Western system of democracy was that, when presidents or prime ministers lost elections, far from being shot, they went off into honoured retirement with a pension and that this, therefore, made them more scrupulous in conducting elections and less likely to take extreme measures to avoid being removed from office.

speech.para: I would not say this was a complete revelation to him, but it gave him a lot of food for thought. It occurred to me as I was sitting there that it underlined what a very, very big cultural gap there was. Of course, in a lot of these countriesâand Russia is a very good case in pointâyou had enormous differences in terms of the cultural awareness of how democracies work and how the rule of law works. You had an elite group, many of whom had worked with the foreign ministry, and particularly with the foreign intelligence service, who had quite a bit of experience of the Western world and understood very well how it operated. But there were many others who had no idea at all. One of the interesting contrasts between the Soviet Union and Chinaâa very significant difference in my viewâis that, right up until the fall of communism in the Soviet Union, very few Russians were educated outside the Soviet Union or were educated in the West, unless they had left in an unauthorised way.

China, on the other hand, from the end of the Cultural Revolution has been exporting thousandsâit must by now be hundreds of thousands if not millionsâof students to the West. When I was doing business at this time, about 10 years ago, in both China and Russia, the thing that struck me was how few Russians spoke English, how few had an understanding of the Western world, and yet I would then flyâgenerally from Irkutsk to Shenyang and then down to Beijingâto China and it was a complete transition. The middle-aged leadership in China invariably spoke English. Some also spoke European languagesâthey had been educated in France or Germanyâand they had a level of worldliness and sophistication that was completely different. They had few counterparts in Russia.

When the member for Fraser and I were in Dalian about a decade ago the mayor of the city at that time was a man called Bo Xilai, who is now I think the Minister for Commerce, the son of a very distinguished revolutionary hero. Bo Xilai spoke English almost unaccented. I went out with him one evening as he was meeting and greeting his constituents and it was like campaigning with a Chinese John F Kennedy. He had so much charisma and style. He represented the complete antithesis of what you would imagine a Communist Party leader would represent. So China, notwithstanding it has remained a communist dictatorship, nonetheless opened itself up to the West and to Western ideas and to education and to trade long before the Soviets did. As a result, these former Soviet countries have had a lot of catching up to do.

The major issue for the EBRD going forward is the one I mentioned earlier, and it is something that the United States representative at their recent annual general meeting, Randall Quarles, the Acting Under Secretary for the Treasury, pointed out very forcefully. He said that the EBRDâs work is basically done in Central Europeâin the EU8 and Croatia. Those countries have transitioned into the European Union. Several of them are wealthier than the countries of old Europe. I think Estonia and Slovenia now are wealthier on a per capita basis than Portugal, for example. So while there is a lot of progress to be had, there are plenty of other agencies and indeed the private sector to help them out. The real challenge nowadays is right in the heart of the CIS. There is a major challenge in Belarus, where there has been no move to democracy comparable to the Ukraine, and there are major challenges in Central AsiaâTajikistan, Turkmenistan and, of course, Uzbekistan. That is where the focus needs to be.

The member for Fraser questioned what Australian firms get out of it. Australians are a very entrepreneurial and globally minded people. Indeed, my old friend John Thornton, together with several colleagues, when he was running Goldman Sachs used to say that he thought that Australians were the ideal global investment bankers because they came from a very ethnically diverse country, a very multicultural country, and did not have the sense of cultural superiority that perhaps some other nations who remain nameless might have. Australians work globally very well. That is why there is a million or so of us living outside Australiaâand many of them are in business.

Australians will do well wherever there is free trade: wherever borders are open, wherever corruption is eliminated or at least reduced, wherever legal systems are straightforward, wherever taxes, dare I say it, are simple and lowâindeed, there is a lot for us to learn from the efforts of countries in Central and Eastern Europe who have moved to simpler and in some cases almost flat taxes. Wherever it is easy for people to do business, trade will follow, prosperity will follow trade and Australians will be in the vanguard because we are an enterprising people and our enterprise will benefit from those countries that open up their markets and reform their legal systems.

Contrary to the member for Fraser, whose efforts in introducing Australia to the EBRD were of course very commendable in the days when he was trade minister, I have no doubt that Australia benefits from the work of the EBRD as we benefit from the march of freedom, both political and economic, and from the development of a greater respect everywhere for the rule of law. We benefit from that as do the countries in which we invest and with whom we trade.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI will start my summing up remarks by thanking honourable members for their contributions, particularly the members for Bowman and Wentworth for their very learned and erudite contributions to the debate on this important initiative. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Amendment Bill 2005 implements an important commitment made by Australia to Mongolia to assist in its economic and social development by allowing it access to investment funding from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, otherwise known as âthe bankâ.

speech.para: Australia does value the friendly relations it shares with Mongolia. Diplomatic relations were established in 1972 and have been recently strengthened by a parliamentary delegation visit to Mongolia earlier this year. Australia and Mongolia also share a common voice as members of the same constituency at both the International Monetary Fund and, of course, the World Bank.

The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development was established in 1991 to support central and eastern European and ex-Soviet countries in the creation of a new private sector in a democratic environment. Today, the bank uses the tools of investment to help build market economies and democracies in some 27 countries from central Europe to central Asia. Mongolia has made significant progress in implementing economic reform and encouraging private sector growth. Australia recognises that the bank is ideally placed to assist in future private sector development. These amendments will greatly encourage such reforms.

The Treasurer, as Australiaâs governor on the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, voted in favour of Mongoliaâs membership of the bank, thereby making it eligible to receive development financing. All other governors strongly supported this resolution by unanimously voting in support. The bill implements this commitment by amending article 1 of the agreement establishing the bank to specifically include Mongolia as a country of operations going forward. Importantly, the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties has supported this amendment and recommended that binding treaty action be taken. This amendment would allow Mongolia to become the 28th country to receive development financing from the bank. The bill also creates a regulation-making power so that any future amendments to the agreement can be made by regulation going forward.

Mongolia can only be admitted to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development once all member countries have completed their ratification processes. Many other countries have recognised Mongolia as a country of operations of the bank, and this amendment would ensure that Australia is in step with other members of the bank. It is important that the House pass this bill so as to allow Australia to fulfil its international treaty obligations. I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill makes various amendments to the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and Defence Act 1903, including the creation of three new statutory appointments for the Director of Military Prosecutions, Registrar of Military Justice and Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force. The amendments indicate the governmentâs ongoing commitment to ensuring an open, transparent and fair military justice system.

The amendments in the bill are consistent with the governmentâs response to the 2005 Senate report into The effectiveness of Australiaâs military justice system. There will be a need for further amendments as additional parts of the governmentâs response to the report are implemented in the near future.

This bill will also give effect to certain recommendations contained in two previous reports made by Brigadier the Hon. Mr Justice Abadee in his study into the judicial system under the Defence Force Discipline Act (the Abadee report) and Mr James Burchett QC in his reportâAn inquiry into military justice in the Australian Defence Force (the Burchett report). The proposed amendments contained in the bill will, among other things, eliminate the role of a convening authority and will allocate these prosecution functions to a âDirector of Military Prosecutionsâ and a âRegistrar of Military Justiceâ. The Burchett report recommended the establishment of the Director of Military Prosecutions as an independent prosecutorial authority for the Australian Defence Force (ADF), which would undertake prosecutions of members of the ADF facing trial by either court martial or Defence Force magistrate under the Defence Force Discipline Act.
I turn firstly to the measures amending the Defence Force Discipline Act set out in schedule 1 of the bill.
There are four major measures included in the bill that relate to the Defence Force Discipline Act.

The first relates to the establishment of a statutory position of the Director of Military Prosecutions. As mentioned, these changes will implement recommendations from the June 2005 Senate report and previous reports into the military justice system. The creation of Director of Military Prosecutions will make the prosecution of serious offences under the Defence Force disciplinary system similar to the prosecution procedures used in the civil criminal system.

In addition to creating the position and specifying the required qualifications for the position and the mechanism for the appointment of the Director of Military Prosecutions, the bill makes provision for the determination of the remuneration of, the provision of staffing to and the roles, functions and powers of Director of Military Prosecutions.

Principally, the Director of Military Prosecutions will be responsible for decisions on what charges should be tried before a court martial or Defence Force magistrate, the provision of a prosecutor for those charges and the power to, if required, either initiate charges or direct that charges not be proceeded with.

The second measure creates a statutory position of the Registrar of Military Justice. The creation of the Registrar of Military Justice also implements recommendations from previous reports into the military justice system to again ensure an open, transparent and fair military justice system. The bill makes provision for the required qualifications, mechanism for appointment and determination of the remuneration of the Registrar of Military Justice, along with the roles, functions and powers of the registrar. The registrar will be responsible for the panelling and administration of courts martial and the administration of Defence Force magistrate trials.

The third measure terminates the establishment of convening authorities. Currently a convening authority is a senior commander appointed by a service chief. The convening authority decides whether the prosecution of a service offence should proceed before a court martial or a Defence Force magistrate, or not at all. The roles of a convening authority will predominantly be distributed between the Director of Military Prosecutions and the Registrar of Military Justice. However, to ensure that the Director of Military Prosecutions is aware of the service aspects of offences, the bill creates the concept of a superior authority. The functions of a superior authority will be performed by senior officers, and most likely by the appointments currently performing functions as convening authorities.

Finally, the bill makes provision for the remuneration of the existing statutory position of the Chief Judge Advocate to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. This is similar to what is proposed for the remuneration of Director of Military Prosecutions and Registrar of Military Justice. It should ensure consistency between the three positions.
The amendments to the Defence Act set out in schedule 2 of this bill relate to the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force.

An essential feature of an effective armed service is the need for discipline which is, and is seen to be, rigorously enforced. Failures in the military justice system, when they occur, not only soon become publicly known, but, if not properly dealt with, can quickly result in damage to reputation, morale and, ultimately, operational effectiveness. The military justice system must meet its obligations to ensure that ADF members are treated fairly and in accordance with the law.

In the 2001 Burchett report it was recommended that a military inspector-general be appointed to provide the Chief of the Defence Force with constant scrutiny of the military justice system, independent of the ordinary chain of command.

To give effect to this recommendation, the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force was administratively established with effect from 13 January 2003. The role of the Inspector-General ADF is to provide the Chief of the Defence Force with ongoing review of the military justice system, independent of the ordinary chain of command. This includes both ADF discipline and defence inquiries system.

To ensure that the position is independent of the normal military chain of command and has the capacity to act impartially and with the appropriate authority, the bill will formalise the position in the Defence Act.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition support the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005 in recognition that it represents at least some progress in improving the military justice system. But we do note that this is the first time for many years that the Howard government has done anything about what has been described by a bipartisan Senate committee examining this topic as virtually a dysfunctional military justice system. The Minister for Veteransâ Affairs talked in her contribution about the significance of instances of abuse, which is unquestionably true. She referred to publicity of these events, distress on individuals and the ruining of careers, which are all absolutely true. We see on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald today, for instance, yet a further allegation of what can only be described, if sustained, as sick conductâworse than weirdâin respect of a young female reservist, which must be addressed.

speech.para: I would go further than the minister went. I would say that allegations of abuse and instances of bastardisation, bullying and abuse have now become a national security issue. There is no question of the perception of its existence. Figures revealed by the minister in answer to a question on notice that I received yesterday reveal that there are extensive instances of abuse. They have, unquestionably, a disincentive effect on recruitment and they also, I believe, necessarily must have an effect on retention rates.

For instance, the figures show that 2.1 per cent of all naval personnelâthat includes both permanents and reservistsâhave complained about unacceptable behaviour. Last year 12 per cent of our Navy personnel decided to leave the service. How many of these vital sailors are we losing because of sexual harassment, workplace bullying and other forms of unacceptable behaviour? The figures show that five per cent of all Army personnel complained about unacceptable behaviour. Last year 13 per cent of our troops made the decision to leave. Again I ask: how many of these men and women made their decision because of a culture of bullying and abuse, whether that was of themselves or what they witnessed? In the Air Force 0.6 per cent complained about unacceptable behaviour. Last year eight per cent of our Air Force made the decision to leave the services. Again I ask: how many determined to leave because they would not accept inappropriateâindeed, unacceptableâtreatment in their workplace?

These are not frivolous complaints. Indeed, the figures provided to me yesterday show that some 55 per cent of complaints have been upheld. These are serious issues and have to be addressed seriously. I should say at the outset that, in making those points, the opposition acknowledge that the overwhelming majority of Australiaâs serving men and women are incredibly decent and committed Australians and would never consider engaging in unacceptable behaviour in the course of their duties. We also accept and respect the fact that the current Chief of the Defence Force, Air Chief Marshal Houston, has indicated a policy of zero tolerance for unacceptable behaviour in the Defence Force and we accept the genuineness of his commitment. Nonetheless, there are clearly long-term structural problems that exist in our system of military justice, which on any reasonable assessment contribute to a situation where a culture of bullying, bastardisation and abuse can exist.

As I said yesterday, the figures revealed in response to a questionâNo. 1930, for those who are interestedâin which I asked the minister to break down annual report figures of unacceptable behaviour in terms of complaints under the individual subheadings of âsexual offencesâ, âsexual harassmentâ, âgeneral harassmentâ, âdiscriminationâ, âabuse of powerâ, âworkplace bullyingâ and âinappropriate workplace relationshipsâ, show, significantly, that of 749 complaints of unacceptable behaviour across the entire military, including the civilian Department of Defence, 631 were in our armed forcesâa vastly disproportionate number of complaints.

I have already alluded to the fact that the Navy is by far the most alarming example where, out of a total of just over 13,300 permanent and reserve members, there were 45 complaints of sexual offences, 42 of sexual harassment, 132 of general harassment, 14 of abuse of power and 43 of workplace bullying. As I have said, the figures also show that 55 per cent of those cases have been substantiatedâthat is, the complaint has been upheld as valid. As at 30 June 2005, another 23 per cent of those cases have not been finalised but, on the same percentages, we are entitled to assume that the majority of the cases that have yet to be finalised will also be sustained.

The figures for the Navy, which are approximately 5,000 fewer in number than the civilian staffing of the Department of Defence, showed almost three times as many complaints of unacceptable behaviour and, in some categories, were dramatically higher. For instance, as I have said, there were 45 sexual offences complaints in the Navy, whereas there were only two for the civilian Department of Defence. There were 42 complaints of harassment in the Navy and nine in the Department of Defence. There were 43 complaints of workplace bullying in the Navy and 29 in the Department of Defence.

A comment reported in the media today that our Defence Force figures replicate what can be expected in a normal workplace is certainly not the case. These figures demonstrate that there is a disproportionate number of complaints in our armed forces and, as I have indicated, a substantial numberâthe majority of 55 per centâof those have been found to have been upheld. On any measure, these figures are totally unacceptable.

The recent Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, in its report, The effectiveness of Australiaâs military justice system, considered evidence from a number of personnel and families of previously serving servicemen and women, and they outlined a number of tragediesâseveral suicidesâthat have occurred as a result of this sort of conduct.

In todayâs media we have again seen reports of allegations of completely unacceptable behaviourâas I have said, more than unacceptable, absolutely sick behaviourâif it occurred. These issues are more than concerning; they are now to the point of being a national security issue. As the Chief of the Defence Force has said, the recruitment of talented young Australians into our Defence Force is a pressing priority for the long-term skill base of our military; hence the technological edge that we have in our region. Yet, despite our knowledge of the existence of this culture, as found by that bipartisan committee, this is effectively the first time for 10 years that the Howard government has introduced measures to in some small way at least reform the military justice system. This is despite the fact that over the past 10 years there have been six major reviews of the military justice system, not including the most recent Senate inquiry to which I have referred.

In part, the bill we are considering arose, as the minister indicated, from the Abadee report commissioned by the Department of Defence in 1995 by the then Chief of the Defence Force, General Baker, which was submitted to the general in August 1997. Essentially that report recommended greater autonomy be granted to Defence legal personnel from the normal military chain of command. It is acknowledged that the bill goes some way to achieving that.

The second major report that forms the basis of part of the current legislation is the Burchett report, which was submitted to the then Chief of the Defence Force, Admiral Barrie, in July 2001. Again the motivation for the instigation of that report was numerous complaints of unacceptable and violent behaviour across the Defence Force. In his report Justice Burchett noted an unhealthy culture of âkeeping things in-houseâ. His Honour noted in respect of objectionable practices in training and justice occurring at military institutions:

quote.para: Under the heading âKeeping Things âIn-Houseââ, reference is made to the suggestion, which came up in discussion groups, that COs were tempted to maintain appearances in respect of their commands by keeping matters that ought to be prosecuted âin-houseâ. Sometimes, of course, this may have been the observerâs perception. But sometimes it may really happen.

speech.para: That is the finding in the report. We are concerned that this perception that things can still be kept in-house has not been sufficiently addressed by the government. The concept of âCaesar judging Caesarâ is very much a concern that exists in the community and certainly, as indicated by the Senate report, in the majority of parliamentarians.

The Burchett report recommended the establishment of an office of Director of Military Prosecutions as an independent prosecutorial authority for the Australian Defence Force. It was recommended that the office take responsibility for prosecutions of members of the Defence Force facing trial by court martial or a Defence Force magistrate under the Defence Force Discipline Act. This aspect of the report is again substantially implemented in the legislation we are considering and is supported by the opposition.

In April 2001, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade handed down a report entitled Rough justice? An investigation into allegations of brutality in the Armyâs parachute battalion. It was Report No. 99, commonly known as the Rough justice report. As indicated in the title, that report concerned allegations of misconduct in the 3rd Battalion of the Royal Australian Regiment. There have also been several other reports that have either directly or indirectly questioned the effectiveness of Australiaâs military justice system, including the Defence Force Ombudsmanâs report in January 1998.

As I say, the measures contained in the bill in some way reflect the recommendations of those previous reports, as outlined by the minister, but, other than in an extremely limited way, they do not reflect those of the most recent inquiry by the Senate Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade References Committee, to which I have referred. That bipartisan report found:

quote.para: After extensive consideration and significant evidence, the committee considers that the ADF has proven itself manifestly incapable of adequately performing its investigatory function.

speech.para: It further found:

quote.para: Evidence to the committee cast considerable doubt over the impartiality of current structures.

speech.para: Shortcomings identified in the report included: the prevalence of untrained investigators; inordinate delays in the system; a poor quality of investigations; poor evidence gathering; a failure of procedural fairness; a lack of independence; inordinate delays in reviews; a lack of independence in the review process; a lack of impartiality; a failure to act on recommendations; a failure to keep complainants informed and to protect them; breaches of confidence; and abuse of powersâto summarise the more significant of those findings. It is regrettable that the government has decided not to implement the complete recommendations of the Senate committee. We recognise that the government has indicated additional legislation will be introduced, but nonetheless that legislation will not, as we understand it, implement the full recommendations of the committee.

The substance of the current bill has been outlined by the minister in her second reading speech. I will not repeat the substance. Rather, I will restrict my comments to general concerns about the inadequacy that is still there in the operation of these provisions. Firstly, in respect of the establishment of a statutory Director of Military Prosecutions, we welcome the statutory office being a full-time appointment. That will substantially consolidate the directorâs position and functions. However, we note that under the bill the director will be appointed by the minister and the director will also be required to submit an annual report to the minister. The subordination of the director to ministerial authority does not, we believe, sufficiently remove the director from the influence of the military chain of command, which view was expressed in the Senate report to which I have referred.

The Senate report expressed concern that internally appointed administrators of military justice might remain subservient to their military superiors and that, at the very least, there might be a perception that those seeking justice would believe that they would have difficulty in receiving a fair and sympathetic hearing in the context of a situation where those administering justice remained subject to a higher military command. We note in particular that while the director will not be appointed internally he or she will nonetheless be appointed from within the military ranks. Indeed, one of the criteria of the appointment is that the director must be either a permanent member of the military or a reservist rendering continuous full-time service. Unquestionably, in that context, the director will remain, we believe, subject to higher military command. In that context, we note, for instance, that, under the bill, the directorâs minimum ranking has been increased to commodore, brigadier or air commodore, which, as I understand it, is the equivalent of a one-star general ranking. That we would concede is consistent with recommendation No. 14 of the Senate committee report. However, the reality remains that the proposed Director of Military Prosecutions, in making the decision to prosecute charges, will take over that decision-making process from some 30 or so officers with a ranking equivalent to one- and two-star general ranking, and it remains the case that, as a statutorily appointed director, he or she may still operate in the shadow of those more senior command officers.

The nature of the appointment is also important, because under the bill the directorâs powers will include powers in respect of civilian, criminal and military discipline offences, not just military discipline offences. The recommendation of the Senate report was to restrict the DMPâs functions to military discipline functionsâspecifically, that the director:

quote.para: ... should only initiate a prosecution in the first instance where there is no equivalent or relevant offence in civilian criminal law.

speech.para: Generally, the structure of the office is inappropriate to that of an impartial prosecutorial authority. For instance, one of the directorâs functions is to represent the interests of the service chiefs at any hearing before the Defence Force Discipline Appeal Tribunal. Clearly, this function in itself pollutes, at least from the point of view of perception, appropriate lines of separateness, accountability and independence.

A further recommendation of the Burchett inquiry that is adopted in the bill is the creation of the office of Inspector-General of the ADF. The office was created administratively in January 2003, and under the bill a statutory appointment of Inspector-General of the ADF would be made by the minister. Again, we recognise and welcome the fact of statutory appointment. But, in making that appointmentâin the appointment processâthe minister must have regard to the recommendation of the Chief of the Defence Force. As I have indicated, I have tremendous respect for not only the Chief of the Defence Force but also the current Minister for Defence, but it can be seen that this procedure, which requires the minister to have regard to the CDFâs recommendation, when combined with the requirement for military experience on the part of the candidate, may again, at least from the point of view of perception, bring the independence of the position into question. Despite the sincerity and decency of those involved in the decision-making process, the perception is affected.
Of significance was the fact that the Senate report specifically questioned the need for the inspector-general to have military knowledge, noting:

quote.para: ...Â the Defence Force Ombudsman and his staff have performed their administrative review function for many years without this military background.

speech.para: I note that the government has taken the opposite emphasis with its explanatory memorandum, arguing that the position of Inspector-General ADF can only work successfully if he or she enjoys the confidence of the Chief of Defence Force and is able to work with the Chief of Defence Forceâhence the justification for input by the CDF in the selection process.

But again this should be looked at in the light of ongoing occurrences of unacceptable behaviour and in the light of a reluctance on the part of young potential recruits to enter the defence forcesâa reluctance that is a result, I believe, of the perception of that culture. On the figures I referred to earlier in this speech, that is probablyâit remains to be researched, but commonsense would suggest thisâa factor in retention rates. Viewed in that light, the first and foremost priority of the Inspector-General ADF should be that he or she enjoy the confidence of the Australian community.

Another concern we have with the office is the fact that, whereas the Burchett inquiry recommended that the inspector-general be given specific power to refer matters to civil police, the bill is quite vague in respect of that particular function of the inspector-general. It merely includes a statement about âreferring matters to other appropriate authorities to be dealt withâ. That matter, we believe, should be clarified specifically. We are also concerned that the inspector-general is only to report to the CDF as directed by the CDF. In particular, that provision suggests a less than complete determination on the part of the government to change the culture that was found by the Senate inquiry to exist within our military. In particular, it shows less than a commitment to what the government claims as its priorityâthe development of a transparent and fair military justice system. Again, in the context of the explanatory memorandum we believe that the inspector-general should have as a significantâif not primaryâpurpose the preparation of reports in order to publicly expose failures in the military justice system so that they can be properly examined and remedial action taken.

I want to move to another statutory office under the bill. The office of the Registrar of Military Justice will undertake some administrative duties currently undertaken, as the minister indicated, by the convening authorities. Again this is a measure which the opposition welcomes. It will hopefully avoid the potential for conflict that currently exists in the system, where convening authorities undertake both prosecution and administrative duties with respect to the progress of a disciplinary or criminal trial process. Indeed, it is fair to say that the majority of complaints that come across my desk in my capacity as a shadow ministerâand, occasionally, in my capacity as a member of the House of Representativesâin respect of delay and lack of outcome on the part of those seeking review of their treatment within the military relate to that very phenomena of the prosecution being the manager of the actual complaint or disciplinary process.

However, we believe it would have been desirable for the registrar to be able to make interlocutory and interim orders regarding the progress of litigation, just as a registrar in a civilian court frequently has this power. For instance, in some cases it may be appropriate for orders to be made with respect to discovery of documents. In other cases it may be appropriate for there to be some direction regarding expedition of a case, particularly in circumstances where evidence suggested physical or mental trauma as a result of the circumstances confronting the complainant.
We also expressed concerns that under the bill, as the explanatory memorandum states, superior authorities will be appointed to:

quote.para: â¦ represent the Service interest in pursuing a matter at the court martial or Defence Force magistrate level.

speech.para: We believe it is unsatisfactory that the bill does not effectively identify and delineate the role of that superior authority or the relevant rank of the superior authority. It is quite possible, for instance, that a superior authority may be a two-star rank or more senior, whereas the Director of Military Prosecutions will in all likelihood be a one-star officer. This is again a clear situation where, if the supervising authority is a more senior officer, there will be enormous pressure on the more junior-ranking officer occupying the position of Director of Military Prosecutions to be at least subconsciously subservient to that superior authority. We believe it is also inappropriate for those superior authorities to be responsible for organising the legal representations of an accused person, given that their primary obligation and role under the legislation is to represent the interests of the ADF. Again, in that context, it is regrettable that the government has not adopted the recommendation of the Senate report to establish an independent position of director of defence counsel service.

In summary, while this bill is welcomed to the extent that it does implement some recommendations of previous inquiries, it does not address those fundamental structural issues to which I have referred. In particular, it does not seek to distinguish between the military justice system and control by the militaryâin other words, the concept of Caesar judging Caesar, which I referred to at the outset of my speech. While this legislation was not available to the Senate inquiry, it is again reflective of a government approach to the military justice system which was described by the Senate committee as being âbroadly reactive and piecemealâ.

In short, this proposed legislative framework does, to a degree, separate the prosecution and administrative functions between the Director of Military Prosecutions and the registrar and does give greater autonomy to the three statutory appointments that have been referred to. However, problems with that appointment process in itself, the qualification for office of those office-holder, and the influence or potential for influence to be brought to bear on those office-holders by more senior officers under the procedures set out in the bill do not significantly change or sufficiently change that dynamic of control of the military justice system by the military hierarchy itself.

For those reasons, much more needs to be done, and we would again ask the government to consider the recommendations of the Senate committee to which I have referred, which had the philosophy of very much effecting a demarcation of functions between the military and civilian authorities. In conclusion, for the reasons outlined, we support the legislation. I move:

item.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:
(1)Â Â condemns the Government for its failure to implement in full the recommendations of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee report on military justice 2005;

(2)Â Â notes that the measures contained in this bill will not be sufficient to address the issues of bullying, harassment, victimisation, intimidation, bias and failure of natural justice which have been revealed so regularly in the last decade; and

(3)Â Â notes that unless the Government properly deals with this matter in a determined fashion, the reputation of Australiaâs armed forces will continue to be unfairly sullied and remain a deterrent for talented young Australians to join the ADFâ.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BC Scott)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

âI listened with interest to the contribution made by the honourable member for Barton to the debate on the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005. It seemed to me that he was damning this bill with faint praise, but I was pleased at the end to hear that the opposition are in fact supporting this bill, although they would have liked the bill to have gone somewhat further. The government clearly is not prepared to accept the second reading amendment moved by the member for Barton, and no doubt the minister at the table will elaborate in detailed form as to why the second reading amendment is not acceptable.

speech.para: This bill will continue to enhance the military justice system to bring about improved impartiality, rigour, transparency and even better outcomes. The reforms will help make sure that there is an ongoing maintenance of effective discipline in the Australian Defence Force and will also protect individuals and their rights. I think all of us on both sides of the House are at one insofar as we want to see a military justice system that works, is equitable and is fair, but I believe that the system as it currently exists and as amended by this legislation is a system worthy of high regard. I do not have the concerns expressed by my friend the honourable member for Barton.

This bill makes a number of amendments to the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and the Defence Act 1903, including the creation of three new statutory appointments for the Director of Military Prosecutions, the Registrar of Military Justice and the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force. This indicates once and for all that we want an open, transparent and fair military justice system. There are many benefits included in this legislation to help achieve that end. The Director of Military Prosecutions will provide an independent prosecuting authority, thus ensuring that decisions on whether or not to prosecute at a Defence Force magistrate and court martial level are made in a fair and unbiased manner. Additionally, the person holding the office of the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force will provide the Chief of the Defence Force with an ongoing review of the military justice system, independent of the ordinary chain of command. This includes both the ADF discipline and defence inquiry systems.

The honourable member for Barton in his speech devoted what I thought was an inordinate amount of time to expressing concerns that military officers who are sitting on courts could in some way, shape or form be directed by even more senior officers. He conceded that only officers of high rank would be able to carry out these judicial functions but somehow thought that the equivalent of a one-star general might be subjected to direction from higher military officers. I am sure the member for Barton did not intend to impugn the character of those higher officers in the Australian Defence Force, but the effect of what he said is that officers carrying out their roles in the defence judicial system could in some way be dictated to by those at a higher level. I do not believe that in 2005, given the transparency that is in the system and also given the fact that we have only senior officers of a very high quality, this is a concern which should have any veracity at all.

The bill is required to ensure that the military justice system meets its obligations to ensure that ADF members are treated fairly and in accordance with the law. This is clearly not the first piece of legislation in this area. Previous legislation has implemented a number of recommendations from previous reviews into the military justice system. The member for Barton spoke at length about the Senate report. Just because the Senate has given a report does not necessarily mean that the government is obligated to implement everything included in that Senate report. What the government does with the report of any parliamentary committee is look at what is included and then decide what is worthy of implementation and what should be either considered further or rejected.

The essential element of this legislation is to ensure that we have appropriate discipline and the ability to enforce discipline in an effective armed service. Failures in the military justice system, when they occur, have become very publicly known and, if not dealt with expeditiously, can in a very fast way result in damage to the way that the Australian public considers the Australian Defence Force. This bill has been subjected to wide consultation. I believe that it is a very effective bill.

The military justice system is integral to military discipline, critical to operational effectiveness and a core responsibility of command. The purpose of the system of military justice is to allow the Australian Defence Force to deal with matters that pertain directly to the effectiveness, efficiency and morale of the military. Effectiveness and efficiency in the challenging environment of military operations require highly disciplined behaviour from our people governed by our system of military justice. It is important that we train at home with the same system that we use on operations to avoid confusion, operational ineffectiveness and unjust treatment.

Perhaps the member for Barton might not concede this, but for most on this side of the House it is obvious that our civil legal system does not have the provisions required to fully support military operations, which do need a very strict maintenance of order, discipline and, quite clearly, teamwork. The military justice system provides a stand-alone code where a civilian jurisdiction may not apply or does not exist. It also provides a means to deal with misconduct that might otherwise be subject to the jurisdiction of foreign countries or the International Criminal Court. That is a very important point. I would much prefer to see our service men and women dealt with under our military justice system than have them carted off before the courts of foreign countries or, for that matter, the International Criminal Court.

I do not know whether the opposition is aware that the Australian Defence Force currently refers serious crimes and crimes where there is no obvious service connection to civilian police for investigation or prosecution in Australia. This has been the case for quite some time and will continue to be the case. I suppose you could say that in a certain way we have our cake and eat it too. Defence will continue work that is under way to improve the management and effectiveness of the relationship between the military and civilian authorities on referral cases. This will include reviewing and clarifying the guidelines and examining the need for and implementing as required formal arrangements with the states and territories for referral of offences.

I do not think that anyone should consider that the Defence Force Discipline Act is a duplication of the criminal system. Jurisdiction under that act for any offence may only be exercised where it can be reasonably regarded as substantially serving the purpose of maintaining or enforcing service discipline, a purpose different from that served by the criminal law.

I said at the outset that I was pleased to see the opposition supporting this bill. Ultimately, I am quite convinced that the second reading amendment will not succeed, that this bill will quite become quickly part of the law of Australia and that, when it does, we will achieve an even better military justice system. I commend the bill to the chamber.

talk.start.para: âIt is my privilege to attend today to speak about the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005. The process by which we look at the administration of justice within the military in Australia is a very important question. I have to say that I think the Australian military already has a culture that establishes itself head and shoulders above most other equivalent bodies the world over. I think we have real reason to be very proud of the military in Australia.

speech.para: Their recent history, in particular in their conduct of a wide range of different deployments, has reflected well on the military and on this nation. Their ability to adapt to those different circumstances is now, I think, recognised the world over. It is understood by troops from other nations that they work alongside. I think those troops admire and respect the systems that we have in place for establishing rules of engagement and for establishing the chain of command and ensuring that it is established on firm ground. The rules within which our troops seek to carry out their duties are clear and understood by all and, at the end of the day, if there is a problem, if there is an issue that arises, it can be addressed quickly and in a way that facilitates, rather than impedes, the mission. This is something that I think is now abundantly clear in places as far away as Afghanistan and Iraq but which has also been on display in recent times in places such as Timor and here in Australia itself. You do not have to go to Iraq or to Afghanistan to see displayed before you the tremendous capability and high morale of the Australian defence forces, the tremendous skills they have at their command and the intelligence and capability of their officers and troops in general. We have every reason to be very proud of this great asset of our nation. Such a strong and well-disciplined military is a credit to Australia, and I am immensely proud of it.

Recently I was fortunate, along with other members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, to visit Iraq to see the troops in that environment. Every time I visit Royal Australian Air Force Base Amberley or other bases in Australia and every time I meet with other groups of service men and women in this country, I always feel very confident about their abilities. Let me say that those abilities were even more on display in Iraq. Our troopsâ strength of character, their purposefulness in the task that they are carrying out and their ability to maintain high morale and execute what is often a very difficult task can never be more adequately displayed than at Al Muthanna in Camp Smitty, where they are based in southern Iraq, or with the security detachment in Baghdad itself, where they are guarding the Australian ambassador and facilitating his activities in Baghdad.

We have people working in those environments who have so many different calls on their talents, so many different competing interests and so many different judgments that they have to makeâon a second-by-second basis at times; they will have something that has to be decided instantly there on their plateâand they do it so very well. I want to report an example of something that reflects very well on the ability of our troops to think on their feetâand on their ability to find effective solutions to what can be the kinds of problems you would never anticipate.

You have to understand for a start that in Iraq our troops are concerned about roadside bombs in particular. Roadside bombsâin Baghdad and places like that particularly but also in Al Muthannaâhave been quite fiendish weapons in the recent past. They have been devised using extreme high technology and that, coupled with high explosive power, has been used to deadly effect to tear apart life and limb and to create havoc where possible. Wherever the insurgents want to try to destroy the efforts to rebuild Iraq, they can bring in these weapons and establish them by the roadside and cause huge loss of life and limb. It is a credit to our troops that they continue to maintain effective campaigns to fight down those sorts of weapons.

But the point I want to makeâand I think it is something that needs to be considered in this billâwas that on a patrol in the Al Muthanna area our troops happened upon a group acting in what you could describe as a suspicious manner. They came across a group of civiliansâapparently civiliansâand one of them was carrying a rifle, an AK47, and another was carrying a shovel, and they were walking along near the roadway in an area where there are quite a lot of irrigation bund walls and things like that. If you wanted to jump to the conclusion that those people were probably outâit was the middle of the nightâseeking to place a roadside bomb in that environment, I do not think many people would blame you for leaping to that assumption: there is a group of people, which includes a person with a shovel and somebody else armed with a rifle, and they are going along.

Our troops did not jump to that conclusion. They did not, as perhaps some others might have, immediately leap in and engage those people with fire or take some pre-emptive step like that. Our troops approached them and discovered that what they were actually doing was seeking to steal water from another farm. These people were out merely seeking to divert water from another crop onto their crop in the middle of the night. This was an activity that was frowned upon by their neighbours, but quite obviously they were not engaged in planting a roadside bomb. Our troops were able to identify that, and they acted appropriately. You can see that, in seeking to determine the business of those people in the way that they did, they took risks themselves. They placed themselves at risk when it might have been so much easier just to launch in there. Seeing people armed and acting suspiciously, they could have moved straight in and perhaps been forgiven for making an assumption about what those people were up to.

That example shows the command system, the rules of engagement and the mind-set of our troops, who are working in a concerted effort to deliver a positive outcome. It is no wonder that our troops have a good rapport with the local community. As I understand it, that incident was widely reported in the Al Muthanna area and people in that area recognised that our troops had acted with great honour and courage in the way that incident was carried out.
