When news of just that one incident travels around the local community, people say, âThese guys arenât trigger happy and they have a real willingness to understand our local community and to act in its best interests.â Such things work very well, and they then play out in the way our troops are able to carry out their tasks.

That example shows the wonderful concert of the various forces being exercised by commanders in the field and by ordinary troops in going about a patrol. These are things that I think Australians should be very proud of. It bodes well for our future relations with the emerging nation of Iraq that these are the grounds on which we are building our engagement there.

I give that little example, but I want to go on into this case. Can you imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker, how it would be possible to properly oversee such a set of circumstances as that if we had a military justice system which was being run from outside by some sort of third-party civilian type operation? I just do not think that troops would feel at all confident in such a system. I do not believe they would feel supported. I do not believe they would feel confident about consistency in their orders and the way in which the rules would be applied, particularly after the event. I think that their faith in the system comes from having commanders who are fully informed, commanders who acquaint themselves with the rules of engagement and build those and other factors into the way in which they order their troops into deployment in a way that is consistent.

The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2005 has taken the direction that the government has laid out. We want a military justice system in Australia that is built on this great military tradition and that recognises this military tradition as being very good. Our military system is sometimes denigrated by people who are really wise in hindsight and who want to present themselves as being experts in this field from outside the system. I think we would be running up a dry gully if we followed their prescriptions as to how military justice should be organised.

This is a system that builds on all the best capabilities and traditions that our Defence Force represents and seeks to provide even more certainty, even more scrutiny and an even more dispassionate and objective analysis of the way in which the law applies. It seeks to establish a body of law that then rolls on from that and can continue to give succour to our military personnel who want to follow those traditions and follow that direction into the future.

This bill creates three new statutory appointments: the Director of Military Prosecutions, the Registrar of Military Justice and the Inspector-General of the ADF. The establishment of the position of Director of Military Prosecutions will make the prosecution of serious offences under the Defence Force disciplinary system similar to those procedures used in the civilian criminal system. The bill deals with the specifications of the role, the required qualifications for the position and the mechanism for the appointment of the director.

The bill also sets out provisions for the determination of remuneration and staffing and the roles, functions and powers of the Director of Military Prosecutions. It sets out the responsibilities of the Director of Military Prosecutions as being decisions on what charges should be tried before a court martial or a Defence Force magistrate, provision of a prosecutor, and initiating charges or directing they not be proceeded with. The position provides an independent prosecuting authority and fair and unbiased decisions on when to proceed and by which avenue to proceed. In creating the position of the Registrar of Military Justice, the bill creates a position that will be responsible for the panelling and administration of courts martial and the administration of Defence Force magistrate trials. The bill again sets out the qualifications, mechanisms and roles.

The establishment of convening authorities will be terminated under this legislation. Currently this authority is a senior commander appointed by a service chief who decides whether the prosecution of a service offence should proceed and, if so, whether it should be before a court martial or a Defence Force magistrate. The roles of the convening authority will be split between the Director of Military Prosecutions and the Registrar of Military Justice, with the creation also of a superior authority made up of senior officers. The remuneration of the chief judge advocate will be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. This will make provisions for the positions consistent.

I turn to the Inspector-General of the ADF. Following a recommendation in the 2001 Burchett report, the bill formalises the appointment of the Inspector-General of the ADF to provide the Chief of the Defence Force with constant scrutiny of the military justice system independent of the ordinary chain of commandâanother check and balance in the system. As I say, the system that is being put in place through this legislation picks up the best traditions and the best of the existing system and builds in even more certainty, more scrutiny. It relates to the way in which the civilian system works but it maintains all the priorities and traditions that are so important in maintaining discipline. I diverged for a minute there. Just to finish off on that theme, the Inspector-General of the ADF is also responsible for both ADF discipline and the defence inquiry system. The position has been administratively effective since 2003, with the bill formalising the position in the Defence Act.

I referred to the value of the traditions that have gone before. Why is it so important that we give such strength to existing traditions when we have pressure outside to completely throw the whole thing over and go in a different direction altogether? It is my belief, absolutely, that it is important to recognise that troops come under immense pressure in an environment which can be incredibly hostile. In any kind of environmentâparticularly in the deployed environment, I am sureâthose troops come under massive pressure. They are there on behalf of all Australians. There is a real need for a system of discipline in order for them to be able to withstand that pressure with the greatest effectiveness.

The consequences of a breakdown in discipline in those circumstances are absolutely dire. A breakdown in discipline creates risks in relation to the objective that the troops are trying to achieve. It creates risks to the troops themselves and it creates risks to civilians whose interests they may be seeking to protect. Those kinds of risks are not to be taken lightly. It is not with any degree of frivolity that we should ever consider a wholesale jump from a system that hasâwe have to say, as things standâprovided us with marvellous service from our defence forces, absolutely top-drawer performances. Worldwide, the reputation of our troops in this regard is second to none.

There are a wide number of rules of engagement that now can be applied to these troops. The complexity of the law by which they must carry out their activity seems to compound every time you open a newspaper. The amount of scrutiny and the amount of wisdom with hindsight that is applied to practically every involvement of troops in every circumstance means that those troops need to be operating on a system that is familiar to them, that they respect, that has outside respect and that has checks and balances to ensure that it is efficacious. In almost every overseas deployment, and also in activities that are carried out within Australia, different rules of engagement apply practically every time. It is just not going to be possible to expect those kinds of changes to be made from outside the military system. They have to be internal. They can be supervised internally. They have to be accounted for internally and, at the end of it all, they have to be answered for internally.

The grounds for these changes are clear-cut. That we have proceeded effectively down this path reflects very well on the minister and on the government. The support that we have for this bill from the defence forces is absolutely strong and it is strong also from members of parliament. I am very pleased to have been able to speak on this issue today. I commend the bill to the House. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Fawcett) adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 6 December 2004:

item.para: For how long can the Australian economy sustain imports at almost three times the level of exports?
What advice has he received on the implications for the Australian economy if the imbalance persisted through 2005 and 2006?
What advice has he received on the impact on interest rates of a continuing and growing trade imbalance?

item.para: The 2004â05 release of ABS Catalogue Number 5204.0 showed that in 2004â05, exports were $163.8billion and imports were $189.2billion.
The honourable member is referred to Budget Statement 3, in Budget Paper 1, Budget Strategy and Outlook 2005â06 for a commentary on the outlook for the Australian economy.
The honourable member is referred to section 10(2) of the Reserve Bank Act, which outlines the various factors that the Reserve Bank Board may take into account when setting interest rates.
